div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: Witts, like Physitians never can agree,
When of a different Societie.
And Rabels DropsA brand of patent medicine were never more cry'd down
By all the Learned Doctors of the Town,
Than a New Play whose Author is unknown.
Nor can those Doctors with more Malice sue
(And powerful Purses) the discenting Few,
Than those with an Insulting Pride, do raile
At all who are not of their own CaballA cabal is a secret or private group similar to a political junto or faction. Source: Oxford English Dictionary:
If a Young Poet hitt your Humour right,
You judg him then out of Revenge and Spight.
So amongst men there are Ridiculous Elves,
Who Monkeys hate for being too like themselves.
So that the reason of the grand debate,
Why Witt so oft is damn'd, when good Plays take,
Is, that you CensureTo judge or give an opinion. Source: Oxford English Dictionaryas you love, or hate.
Thus like a Learned Conclave Poets sit,
Catholique Judges both of Sense and Wit,
And Damn or Save, as they themselves think fit.
Yet those who to others faults are so severe,
Are not so perfect but themselves may Erre.
Some write Correct.Coract indeed, but then the whole
(Bating their own Dull stuff i'th' Play) is stole:
As Bees do suck from Flowers their Honey dew,
So they rob others striving to please you.
Some write their Characters Gentile and fine,
But then they do so Toyl for every line,
That what to you does Easie seem, and Plain,
Is the hard Issue of their labouring Brain.
And some th' Effects of all their pains we see,
Is but to Mimick good Extemporie.
Others by long Converse about the Town,
Have Witt enough to write a Lew'd Lampoon,Satire upon another individual. Source: Oxford English Dictionary
But their chief skill lyes in a Bawdy Song.
In short, the only Witt that's now in Fashon,
Is but the gleenings of good Conversation.
As for the Author of this Coming Play,
I ask't him what he thought fit I shou'd say
In thanks for your good Company to day:
He call'd me Fool, and said it was well known,
You came not here for our sakes, but your own.
New Plays are stuff'd with Witts, and with DebochesIndulgence or excess of pleasure. Source: Oxford English Dictionary,

div.stage: The Scene NAPLES(DRAFT-Needs Picture)One of Behn's first significant changes to her source play by Thomas Killigrew is moving the action from Madrid to Naples, rendering the action perhaps even more exotic than in the original. At this time, Naples was ruled by Spain, which explains why so many characters in the play have been traveling back and forth between Naples and places like Madrid and Pamplona. Image: Claude Vernet, View of the Bay of Naples, 1747 (Wikimedia Commons) "img src="http://virginia-anthology.org/home/virgin1/Anthology_texts/Behn_Aphra/Naples-vernet.jpg", in Carnival time.

div.head: THE ROVER:Pirate, or a person who aimlessly wanders and roams. Source: Oxford English Dictionary OR, The Banish't Cavaliers.Supporters of Charles I in the English Civil War between him and the Parliament. Source: Oxford English Dictionary
ACT the First.
Scene the First. A Chamber.

sp.speaker: Florinda
sp.l: What an Impertinent thing is a Young Girl bred in a Nunnery? How full of Questions? PritheeA contraction of "I pray thee," similar to "I beg of you." Source: Oxford English Dictionary no more Hellena, I have told thee more than thou understand'st already.

sp.speaker: Hellena
sp.l: The more's my grief, I wou'd fainBe delighted or glad to. Source: Oxford English Dictionary know as much as you, which makes me so Inquisitive; nor is't enough I know you'r a Lover, unless you tell me too, who 'tis you sigh for.

sp.speaker: Florinda
sp.l: When you'r a Lover, I'le think you fit for a Secret of that Nature.

sp.speaker: Hellena
sp.l: 'Tis true, I never was a Lover yet—but I begin to have a shrew'd guess, what 'tis to be so, and fancy it very pretty to sigh, and sing, and blush, and wish, and dream and wish, and long and wish to see the Man; and when I do look pale and tremble; just as you did when my Brother brought home the fine English Colonel to see you—what do you call him Don Belvill.

l.note: Exclamation of anger or disapproval at perceived mistreatment. Source: Oxford English Dictionary

sp.speaker: Hellena
sp.l: That blush betrays you.—I am sure 'tis so—or is it Don Antonio the Vice-Roy'sThe ruler or governor of a province. Source: Oxford English Dictionary Son?—or perhaps the Rich Old Don Vincentio whom my Father designs you for a Husband?- why do you blush again?

sp.speaker: Florinda
sp.l: With Indignation, and how near soever my Father thinks I am to Marrying that hated Object, I shall let him see, I understand better, what's due to my Beauty, Birth and Fortune, and more to my Soul, then to obey those unjust Commands.

sp.speaker: Hellena
sp.l: Now hang me, if I don't love thee for that dear disobedience. I love mischief strangely, as most of our Sex do, who are come to Love nothing else—but tell me dear Florinda, don't you love that fine AngleseSpanish for an English person.?—for I vow next to loving him my self, 'twill please me most that you do so, for he is so gayFine or noble. Source: Oxford English Dictionary and so handsome.

sp.speaker: Florinda
sp.l: Hellena, a Maid design'dIntended or designated. Source: Oxford English Dictionary for a Nun, ought not to be so Curious in a discourse of Love.

sp.speaker: Hellena
sp.l: And dost thou think that ever I'le be a Nun? or at least till I'm so Old, I'm fit for nothing else—Faith no Sister; andthat which makes me long to know whether you love Belvile, is because I hope he has some mad Companion or other, that will spoil my devotion, nay I'm resolv'd to provide my self this CarnivalSeason before Lent, filled with celebration and festivity. Source: Oxford English Dictionary image from Wikimedia Commons)img src="http://virginia-anthology.org/home/virgin1/Anthology_texts/Behn_Aphra/Johannes Lingenbach-Carnival in Rome 1650.jpg", if there be ere a handsome proper fellow of my humour above ground, tho I ask first.

sp.speaker: Florinda
sp.l: Prithee be not so wild.

sp.speaker: Hellena
sp.l: Now you have provided your self of a Man, you take no care for poor me—prithee tell me, what dost thou see about me that is unfit for Love—have I not a World of Youth? a humour gay? a Beauty passable? a Vigour desirable? well Shap't? clean limb'dWell proportioned. Source: Oxford English Dictionary? sweet breath'd? and sense enough to know how all these ought to be employ'd to the best advantage; yes I do and will, therefore lay aside your hopes of my Fortune by my being a Devote, and tell me how you came acquainted with this Belvile? for I perceive you knew him before he came to Naples.

sp.speaker: Florinda
sp.l: Yes, I knew him at the Siege of Pampulona,Pamplona is a city in the north of Spain, but it's not clear what military action is being referred to here. There was a siege of Pamplona in 1521, but that was more than a century before the events depicted in the play. More generally, however, it was true that during the 1650s, the time during which the action of the play takes place, many English cavaliers were hiring themselves out as mercenary soldiers to armies in contintental Europe, including Spain, so placing military action at Pamplona is quite plausible. However, this is a detail that Behn is lifting from Killigrew's play. he was then a Colonel of French HorseFrench cavalry. Source: Oxford English Dictionary, who when the Town was Ransack't, Nobly treated my Brother and my self, preserving us from all Insolences; and I must own, (besides great Obligations) I have I know not what, that pleads kindly for him about my Heart, and will suffer no other to enter.—But see my Brother.

div.stage: Enter Don Pedro Stephano with a Masquing habitCarnival disguiseand Callis.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: Good morrow Sister.—Pray when saw you your Lover Don Vincentio?

sp.speaker: Florinda
sp.l: I know not Sir—Callis when was he here? for I consider it so little, I know not when it was.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: I have a Command from my Father here to tell you, you ought not to despise him, a Man of so vast a Fortune, and such a Passion for you—Stephano my things.

sp.speaker: Florinda
sp.l: A Passion for me, 'tis more than e're I saw, or he had a desire should be known—I hate Vincentio, Sir, and I wou'd not have a Man so dear to me as my Brother, follow the ill Customes of our Countrey, and make a slave of his SisterIt was customary in prominent families for the father to exert control over whom the daughter marries. This was true in England, but setting the play in Italy enables Behn to stage the conflict between the young women's wishes and their father's control without openly criticizing her own culture.—and Sir, my Father's will, I'm sure you may divert.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: I know not how dear I am to you, but I wish only to be rancktRanked. Source: Oxford English Dictionary in your esteem, equal with the English Coll. Belvile— why do you frown and blush? is there any guilt belongs to the Name of that Cavalier.

sp.speaker: Florinda
sp.l: I'le not deny I value Belvile, when I was expos'd to such dangers as the Licenc'd Lust of common Souldiers threatned, when Rage and Conquest flew through the City—then Belvile this Criminal for my sake, through himself into all dangers to save my Honour and will you not allow him my esteem?

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: Yes, pay him what you will in Honour—but you must consider Don Vincentio's Fortune, and the JoyntureOr "jointure." The property or money given to the wife in marriage. Source: Oxford English Dictionary The amount of a jointure would have been negotiated before the marriage by the two families involved he'l make you.

sp.speaker: Florinda
sp.l: Let him consider my Youth, Beauty and Fortune; which ought not to be thrown away on his Age and Joynture.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: 'Tis true, he's not so young and fine a Gentleman, as that Belvile,—but what Jewels will that Cavalier present you with? those of his Eyes and Heart?

sp.speaker: Hellena
sp.l: And are not those better than any Don Vincentio has brought from the Indies.The West Indies or, more generally, the Americas. Source: Oxford English Dictionary

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: Why how now! has your Nunnery breeding taught you to understand the value of Hearts and Eyes?

sp.speaker: Hellena
sp.l: Better than to believe Vincentio's deserve value from any Woman—he may perhaps encrease her Baggs,Riches, or money-bags. Source: Oxford English Dictionary, but not her Family.That is, he is probably impotent.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: This is fine—go—up to your Devotion, you are not design'd for the conversation of Lovers.

sp.speaker: Hellena
sp.l: Nor Saints, yet a while I hope Aside. I'st not enough you make a Nun of me, but you must cast my Sister away too? exposing her to a worse confinement than a Religious life.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l:
The Girl's mad—it is a confinement to be carry'd into the Countrey, to an Antient Villa belonging to the Family of
the Vincentio's these five hundred Years, and have no other Prospect than that pleasing one of seeing all her own that meets her Eyes—a fine Ayr, large Fields and Gardens, where she may walk and gather Flowers.

sp.speaker: Hellena
sp.l: When by Moon Light? For I am sure she dares not encounter with the heat of the Sun, that were a task only for Don Vincentio and his Indian breeding, who loves it in the Dog dayesHottest part of the summer. Source: Oxford English Dictionary.—and if these be her daily divertisements, what are those of the Night, to lye in a wide Moth—eaten Bed Chamber, with furniture in Fashion in the Reign of King Sancho the FirstKing of Pamplona during the 10th Century. Hellena's joke is that Don Vincentio's furniture is going to be very old and outdated--like himself.; The Bed, that which his Fore—fathers liv'd and dy'd in.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: Hellena
sp.l: This Appartment (new furbrusht and fitted out for the young Wife) he (out of freedom) makes his dressing Room, and being a Frugal and a Jealous CoxcombFool. Source: Oxford English Dictionary, instead of a ValetPersonal attendant. Source: Oxford English Dictionary to uncase his feeble Carcass, he desires you to do that Office—signs of favour I'll assure you, and such as you must not hope for, unless your Woman be out of the way.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: Have you done yet?

sp.speaker: Hellena
sp.l: That Honour being past, the Gyant stretches it self; yawns and sighs a Belch or two, loud as a Musket, throws himself into Bed, and expects you in his foul sheets, and e're you can get your self undrest, call's you with a snore or Two—and are not these fine Blessings to a young Lady?

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: Have you done yet?

sp.speaker: Hellena
sp.l: And this Man you must kiss, nay you must kiss none but him too—and nuzel through his Beard to find his Lips.—And this you must submit to for ThreescoreScore denotes twenty, thus threescore indicates sixty. years, and all for a Joynture.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: For all your Character of Don Vincentio, she is as like to Marry him, as she was before.

sp.speaker: Hellena
sp.l: Marry Don Vincentio! hang me such a Wedlock would be worse than Adultery with another Man. I had rather see her in the Hostel de Dieu,Hostel de Dieu is French for Hostel or Hospital of God. The Hostel de Dieu was a hospital that served the poor operating under a religious order. Source: Wikipedia, to wast her Youth there in Vowes, and be a hand-Maid to LazersA poor or diseased person. Source: Oxford English Dictionary and Cripples, than to lose it in such a Marriage.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: You have consider'd Sister, that Belvile has no Fortune to bring you to, banisht his Countrey, despis'd at home, and pitty'd abroad.

sp.speaker: Hellena
sp.l:
What then? the Vice-Roy's Son is better than that Old Sir Fisty. Don Vincentio! Don Indian! he thinks he's trading to
GamboGambia, a region on the west coast of Africa where Europeans were active in the slave trade from this period well into the 19th century. still, and wou'd Barter himself (that Bell and Bawble)Referring to the costume of court jesters, who wore bells on their heads and carried bawbles. Source: Oxford English Dictionary for your Youth and Fortune.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: Callis take her hence, and lock her up all this Carnival, and at LentThe period immediately after the carnival in the spring; a time of fasting and penance. Source: Oxford English Dictionary. she shall begin her everlasting Pennance in a Monastery.

sp.speaker: Hellena
sp.l: I care not, I had rather be a Nun, than be oblig'd to Marry as you wou'd have me, if I were design'd for't.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: Do not fear the blessing of that choice—you shall be a Nun.

sp.speaker: Hellena
sp.l: Shall I so? you may chance to be mistaken in my way of devotion:—a Nun! yes I am like to make a fine Nun! I have an excellent humour for a GrateA cloistered nun would only be allowed to greet visitors from the world outside the convent through a grate.: no, I'le have a Saint of my own to pray to shortly, if I like any that dares venture on me.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: Callis, make it your business to watch this Wild Cat. As for you Florinda, I've only try'd you all this while and urg'd my Fathers will; but mine is, that you wou'd love Antonio, he is Brave and young, and all that can compleat the happiness of a Gallant Maid—this absence of my Father will give us opportunity, to free you from Vincentio, by Marrying here, which you must do to Morrow.

sp.speaker: Florinda
sp.l: To Morrow!

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: To Morrow, or 'twill be too late—tis not my Friendship to Antonio, which makes me urge this, but Love to thee, and hatred to Vincentio—therefore resolve upon to Morrow.

sp.speaker: Florinda
sp.l: Sir, I shall strive to do, as shall become your Sister.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: I'le both believe and trust you—Adieu

sp.speaker: Hellena
sp.l: As becomes his Sister!—that is to be as resolv'd your way, as he is his—

sp.speaker: Florinda
sp.l: I ne're till now perceiv'd my Ruine near,
I've no defence against Antonio's Love,
For he has all the Advantages of Nature,
The moving Arguments of Youth and Fortune.

sp.speaker: Hellena
sp.l: But heark you Callis, you will not be so cruel to lock me up indeed, will you.

sp.speaker: Callis
sp.l: I must obey the Commands I have—besides, do you consider what a life you are going to lead?

sp.speaker: Hellena
sp.l:
Yes, Callis, that of a Nun: and till then I'll be indebted
a world of Prayers to you, if you'll let me now see, what I never did, the Divertisements of a Carnival.

sp.speaker: Callis
sp.l: What, go in Masquerade? 'twill be a fine farewel to the World I take it—pray what wou'd you do there?

sp.speaker: Hellena
sp.l: That which all the World does, as I am told, be as mad as the rest, and take all Innocent freedomes—Sister you'll go too, will you not? come prithee be not sad.—We'll out—wit Twenty Brothers, if you'll be rul'd by me—come put off this dull humour with your Cloths, and Assume one as gay, and as fantastick, as the Dress my Couzen Valeria, and I have provided, and let's Ramble.

sp.speaker: Florinda
sp.l: Callis, will you give us leave to go?

sp.speaker: Callis
sp.l: I have a Youthful itch of going my self. Aside —Madam, if I thought your Brother might not know it, and I might wait on you; for by my troth I'll not trust Young Girles alone.

sp.speaker: Florinda
sp.l: Thou see'st my Brother's gone already, and thou shalt attend, and watch us.

sp.speaker: Stephano
sp.l: Mad? the Habits are come, and your Couzen Valeria is drest, and stayes for you.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: 'Tis well.—I'll write a Note, and if I chance to see Belvile, and want an opportunity to speak to him, that shall let him know, what I've resolv'd in favour of him.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Come, let's in and dress us.

div.head: SCENE II. A Long Street.
div.stage: Enter Belvile Melancholy, Blunt and Frederick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Whe what the Devil ails the Coll.Colonel In a time when all the World is gay, to look like meer LentFredrick is implying that those who partake in Lent are melencholy and unsatisfied, the traits that Belville is already displaying, several days before Lent has officially started. thus? Had'st thou been long enough in Naples to have been in Love, I shou'd have sworn some such Judgment had befall'n thee.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: No, I have made no new Amours since I came to Naples?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You have left none behind you in Paris?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Neither.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I cannot divine the Cause then, unless the Old Cause, the want of Money.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: And another Old Cause, the want of a Wench— Wou'd not that revive you?

sp.speaker: Blev.
sp.l: You are mistaken, Ned.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Nay, 'Sheartlikins, then thou'rt past Cure.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I have found it out; thou hast renew'd thy acquaintance with the Lady that cost thee so many sighs at the Siege of Pampulona— Pox on't, what d'e you call her—her Brother's a Noble Spaniard—Nephew to the Dead General—Florinda— Ay Florinda—and will nothing serve thy turn but that damn'd virtuous Woman? whom on my Conscience thou lovest in spight too, because thou seest little or no possibility of gaining her.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Thou art mistaken, I have Int'restInterest enough in that lovely Virgins heart, to make me proud and vain, were it not abated by the severity of a Brother, who perceiving my happiness—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Has civily forbid thee the House?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: 'Tis so, to make way for a Pow'rful Rival, the Vice-Roy's Son, who has the advantage of me, in being a Man of Fortune, a Spaniard, and her Brother's Friend, which gives him Liberty to make his CourtPursue courtship, whilst I have recourse only to Letters, and distant looks from her Window, which are as soft and kind
As those which Heav'n sends down on Penitents.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Heyday! 'Sheartlikins, simile! by this Light the Man is quite spoild.—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What the Devil are we made of, that we cannot be thus concern'd for a Wench—'Sheartlikins our Cupids are like the Cooks of the Camp, they can Roast or Boil a Woman, but they have none of the fine tricks to set 'em off, no Hogoes"A notable strong flavor or smell" (Oxford English Dictionary) to make the SawceSauce pleasant and the Stomach sharp.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I dare swear I have had a hundred as young kind and handsom as this Florinda; and Dogs eat me, if they were not as troublesom to me i'th Morning, as they were welcome o'reOver Night.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: And yet I warrant, he wou'd not touch another Woman, if he might have her for nothing.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: That's thy joy, a cheap Whore.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l:
Whe I 'Sheartlikins I love a Franck Soul—when did you ever hear of an honest Woman that took a Man's Money? I warrant
'em good ones—but Gentlemen, You may be free, you have been kept so poor with Parliaments and Protectors, that the little Stock you have is not worth preserving—but I thank my Stars, I had more Grace than to forfeit my Estate by Cavaliering.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Methinks only following the Court, shou'd be sufficient to entitle 'em to that.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: 'Sheartlikins, they know I follow it to do it no good, unless they pick a hole in my Coat"To find fault with one; to fix on some small offense as censurable" (Dictionary of Phrase and Fable) for lending you Money now and then, which is a greater Crime to my Conscience, Gentlemen, than to the Common-Wealth.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Ha! dear Belvile! noble Colonel!

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Willmore! welcom ashore, my dear Rover!—what happy wind blew us this good Fortune?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Let me salute my dear Fred. and then Command me.— How is't honest Lad?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Faith, Sir, the Old Complement, infinitely the better to see my dear mad Willmore again.—Prithee why camest thou ashore? and where's the Prince?This would be Prince Charles, who would become King Charles II at the Restoration of the Stuart monarchy in 1660.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: He's well, and Reigns still Lord of the watry Element. —I must abord again within a day or two, and my business ashore was only to enjoy my self a little this Carnival.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Pray know our new Friend, Sir, he's but bashful, a raw Traveller, but honest, stout, and one of us.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: That you esteem him, gives him an Intr'est here.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Your Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: But well,—Faith I'm glad to meet you again in a warm Climate, where the kind Sun has its God-like Pow'r still over the Wine and Women—Love and Mirth! are my bus'ness in Naples, and if I mistake not the place, here's an Excellent Market for Chapmena pedler (Oxford English Dictionary) of my humour.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: See, here be those kind Merchants of Love you look for.

div.stage: Enter several Men in Masquing Habits, some playing on Musique, others dancing after, Women drest like Courtizans, with Papers pinn'd on their Breasts, and Baskets of Flowers in their Hands.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: 'Sheartlikins, what have we here?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Now the game begins.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Fine pretty creatures! May a stranger have leave to look and love?—What's here—Roses for every moneth?Willmore is reading one of the "papers" pinned on the dresses of the women, which have enigmatic statements vaguely hinting at the womens' sexual availability.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Roses for every moneth? What means that?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: They are, or wou'd have you think they're courtizans, who here in Naples, are to be hir'd by the moneth.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Kind, and obliging to inform us—Pray where do these roses grow? I wou'd fain plant some of 'em in a bed of mine.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Beware such roses, Sir.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: A pox of fear: I'll be bak't with thee between a pair of sheets, and that's they proper still; so I might but strew such roses over me, and under me—fair one, wou'd you wou'd give me leave to gather at your bushThe double-entendre is pretty obvious here. this idle moneth; I wou'd go near to make some body smell of it all the year after.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: And thou hast need of such a remedy, for thou stink'st of tar and ropes ends, like a dock or pest-houseAn hospital for people suffering from an infectious disease (Oxford English Dictionary).

div.stage: [The Woman puts herself into the Hands of a Man, and Exits.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Nay, nay, you shall not leave me so.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: By all means use no violence here.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Death! Just as I was going to be damnably in love, to have her led off! I could pluck that rose out of his hand, and even kiss the bed, the bush grew in.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No friend to love, like a long voyage at sea.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Except a nunnery, Fred.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Death! But will they not be kind? Quickly be kind? Thou know'st I'm no tame sigher, but a rampant lion of the forrest.

div.stage: Advances from the farther end of the Scenes, two Men drest all over with horns of several sorts, making grimaces at one another, with papers pinn'd on their backs.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Oh the fantastical rogues, how they'r drest! 'Tis a satyre against the whole sex.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: 'Is this a fruit that grows in this warm countrey?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Yes: 'Tis pretty to see these Italians start, swell and stab, at the word cuckoldA husband who is being cheated on by his wife; traditionally, cuckolds were said to wear horns as a sign of their being mastered by another, more virile man.; and yet stumble at horns on every threshold.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: See what's on their back—Flowers of every Night. [Reads. —Ah Rogue! and more sweet than roses of ev'ry moneth! This is a gardiner of Adam's own breeding.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: What think you of those grave People?
—is a wake in EssexEssex was frequently a butt of jokes for Londoners, who saw it as a rural backwater. half so mad or extravagant?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I like their sober grave way, 'tis a kind of legal authoriz'd fornication, where the men are not chid for't, nor the women despis'd, as amongst our dull English, even the monsieurs want that part of good manners.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: But here in Italy, a monsieur is the humblest best bred gentleman—duels are so bafled by Bravo's, that an age shews not one but between a French-man, and a hang-man, who is as much too hard for him on the Piaza,or Piazza; a public space or market square as they are for a Dutchman on the New BridgeThe joke here is that the hangman has beaten the Frenchman in their contest, just as the French beat the Dutch in theirs: a reference to an incident in 1672, when Nieuwerbrug (New Bridge), a Dutch garrison post on a branch of the Rhine, fell to the French.—but see another crew.

div.stage: Enter Florinda, Hellena and Valeria, drest like Gipsies; Callis and Stephano, Lucetta, Philipo and Sancho in Masquerade.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Sister, there's your English Man, and with him a handsome proper fellow—I'le to him, and instead of telling him his Fortune, try my own.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Gipsies on my life—sure these will prattle if a man crosse their hands. [Goes to Hellena. —dear, pretty, (and I hope) young Devil, will you tell an amorous stranger, what luck he's like to have?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Have a care how you venture with me Sir, least I pick your pocket, which will more vex your English humourA mixture of sharp wit and sarcastic comments, than an Italian fortune will please you.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: How the Devil cam'st thou to know my countrey and humour?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: The first I guess by a certain forward impudence, which does not displease me at this time, and the loss of your money will vex you, because I hope you have but very little to lose.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Egad child thou'rt ith' right, it is so little, I dare not offer it thee for a kindness—but cannot you divine what other things of more value I have about me, that I wou'd more willingly part with.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Indeed no, that's the bus'ness of a witch, and I am but a gipsie yet.—Yet without looking in your hand, I have a parlous guess, 'tis some foolish heart you mean, an inconstant English heart, as little worth stealing as your purse.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Nay, then thou dost deal with the Devil, that's certain.— thou hast guest as right, as if thou had'st been one of that number it has languisht for.—I find you'l be better acquainted with it, nor can you take it in a better time; for I am come from sea, child, and Venus not being propitious to me in her own element:The Roman goddess of love, sex, fertility, and victory, Venus was, according to mythology, born of sea-foam. I have a world of love in store—wou'd you wou'd be good natur'd and take some on't off my hands.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Whe—I cou'd be inclin'd that way—but for a foolish vow I am going to make—to dye a maid.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Then thou art damn'd without redemption, and as I am a good Christian, I ought in charity to divert so wicked a design —therefore prithee dear creature let me know quickly when, and where I shall begin to set a helping hand to so good a work.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: If you shou'd prevail with my tender heart (as I begin to fear you will, for you have horrible loving eyes) there will be difficulty in't, that you'l hardly undergo for my sake.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Faith child I have been bred in dangers, and wear a sword, that has been employ'd in a worse cause, than for a handsome kind woman—name the danger—let it be any thing but a long siege—and I'le undertake it.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Can you storm?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Oh most furiously.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: What think you of a Nunnery Wall? For he that wins me, must gain that first.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: A nun! Oh how I love thee for't! There's no sinner like a young Saint—nay now there's no denying me, the Old Lawthe Old Testament had no curse (to a woman) like dying a maid; witness Ieptha'sdaughter.In the book of Judges, Jephtha, having won a major military victory, vows to God that he will sacrifice the first thing he sees on his return home. When he arrives, his daughter rushes out to greet him, and he realizes that he must kill his daughter to fulfill his vow. She agrees, but asks for a reprieve of two months to visit friends in the mounts and to lament the fact that she will die a virgin.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: A very good text this, if well handled, and I perceive Father Captain, you wou'd impose no severe penance on her who were inclin'd to console her self, before she took orders.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: If she be young and handsome.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Ay there's it—but if she be not—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: By this hand, child, I have an implicit faith, and dare venture on thee with all faults—besides, 'tis more meritorious to leave the world, when thou hast tasted and prov'd the pleasure on't. Then 'twill be a virtue in thee, which now will be pure ignorance.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: I perceive good Father Captain, you design only to make me fit for Heaven—but if on the contrary, you shou'd quite divert me from it, and bring me back to the world again, I shou'd have a new man to seek I find; and what a grief that will be—for when I begin, I fancy I shall love like any thing, I never try'd yet.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Egad and that's kind—prithee dear creature, give me credit for a heart, for faith I'm a very honest fellow—Oh, I long to come first to the Banquet of Love! And such a swinging appetite I bring—Oh I'm impatient.—thy lodging sweetheart, thy lodging! or I'm a dead man!

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Why must we be either guilty of fornication or murder if we converse with you men—and is there no difference between leave to love me, and leave to lie with me?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Faith child they were made to go together.

sp.speaker: Lucett.
sp.l: Are you sure this is the man?

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.l: When did I mistake your game?

sp.speaker: Lucett.
sp.l: This is a stranger, I know by his gazing; if he be brisk, he'l venture to follow me; and then if I understand my trade, he's mine, he's English too; and they say that's a sort of good natur'd loving people, and have generally so kind an opinion of themselves, that a woman with any wit may flatter e'm into any sort of fool she pleases.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: 'Tis so—she is taken— I have Beauties which my false Glass at home did not discover.

div.stage: She often passes by Blunt, and gazes on him, he struts and Cocks, and walks and gazes on her.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: This Woman watches me so, I shall get no opportunity to discover my self to him, and so miss the intent of my coming —but as I was saying, Sir,—by this Line you shou'd be a Lover.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: I thought how right you guessed, all men are in Love, or pretend to be so—come let me go, I'm weary of this fooling.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I will not, till you have confest whether the passion that you have vow'd Florinda, be true or false?

div.stage: She holds him, he strives to get from her.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Florinda!

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Softly.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Thou hast nam'd one will fix me here for ever.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: She'll be disappointed then, who expects you this night at the Garden-gate, and if you fail not—as let me see the other hand—you will go near to do—she vows to dye or make you happy.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: What canst thou mean?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: That which I say—Farewel.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Oh charming Sybil stay, complete that joy which as it is will turn into destraction!—where must I be? at the Garden-gate? I know it—at Night you say?—I'll sooner forfeit Heav'n than disobey.

div.stage: Enter Don Pedro and other Masquers, and pass over the Stage.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: Madam, your Brother's here.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Take this to instruct you farther.

div.stage: [Gives him a Letter, and goes off.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Have a care, Sir, what you promise; this may be a Trap laid by her Brother to ruine you.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Do not disturb my happiness with doubts.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: My dear pretty Creature, a Thousand Blessings on thee! still in this habit you say?—and after Dinner at this place.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Yes, if you will swear to keep your heart, and not bestow it between this and that.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: By all the little Gods of Love I swear, I'l leave it with you, and if you run away with it, those Deities of Justice will revenge me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Do you know the hand?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: 'Tis Florinda's.
All Blessings fall upon the virtuous Maid.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Nay, no Idolatry, a sober Sacrifice I'l allow you.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Oh Friends, the welcom'st News! the softest Letter!— nay—you shall all see it! and cou'd you now be serious, I might be made the happiest Man the Sun shines on!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: The reason of this mighty joy?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: See how kindly she invites me to deliver her from the threatned violence of her Brother—will you not assist me?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I know not what thou mean'st, but I'll make one at any mischief where a Woman's concerned—but she'l be grateful to us for the favour, will she not?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: How mean you?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: How shou'd I mean? thou know'st there's but one way for a Woman to oblige me.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Do not prophane—the Maid is nicely virtuous.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Who Pox, then she's fit for nothing but a husband, let her e'n go, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Peace, she's the Colonel's Mistris, Sir.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Let her be the Devil, if she be thy Mistris, I'l serve her— name the way.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Read here this Postscript.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: [Reads.] —Kind Heart, if we Three cannot weave a string to let her down a Garden-Wall, 'twere pity but the Hang-man wove one for us all.

div.stage: At Ten at night—at the Garden-Gate—of which, if I cannot get the Key, I will contrive a way over the Wall—come attended with a Friend or Two.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Let her alone for that, your Womans wit! your fair kind Woman! will out-trick a Broker or a Jew: and contrive like a Jesuit in Chains—but see, Ned Blunt is stolen out after the Lure of a Damsel.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: So, he'll scarce find his way home again, unless we get him cry'd by the Bell-man in the Market-place, and 'twou'd sound prettily—a lost English Boy of Thirty.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I hope 'tis some Common crafty Sinner, one that will fit him; it may be she'll sell him for Perue,that is, Peru, where slaves worked in silver mines the Rogue's sturdy, and wou'd work well in a Mine; at least I hope she'll dress him for our Mirth, cheat him of all, then have him well-favourd'ly bang'd, and turn'd out Naked at Midnight.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Prithee what humour is he of, that you wish him so well?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Why of an English Elder Brother's humour, Educated in a Nursery, with a Maid to tend him till Fifteen, and lyes with his Grand-Mother till he's of Age: one that knowes no pleasure beyond riding to the next Fair, or going up to London with his right Worshipful Father in Parliament-time; wearing gay Cloths, or making honourable Love to his Lady Mothers Landry-MaidA female servant responsible for performing many household responsibilities, including laundry. See Joanna Martin, Wives and Daughters: Women and Children in the Georgian Country House. London: Hambledon and London, 2004.: gets drunk at a Hunting-Match, and ten to one then gives some proofs of his Prowess.—A Pox upon him, he's our Banker, and has all our Cash about him, and if he fail, we are all Broke.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Oh let him alone for that matter, he's of a damn'd stingey quality, that will secure our stock; I know not in what danger it were indeed if the Jilt shou'd pretend she's in Love with him, for 'tis a kind believing Coxcomb; otherwise if he part with more than a piece of Eight—-gueldcastrate him: for which offer he may chance to be beaten, if she be a Whore of the First Rank.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Nay the Rogue will not be easily beaten, he's stout enough; perhaps if they talk beyond his capacity, he may chance to exercise his Courage upon some of them, else I'm sure they'll find it as difficult to beat as to please him.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: 'Tis a luckey Devil to light upon so kind a Wench!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Thou had'st a great deal of talk with thy little Gipsie, coud'st thou do no good upon her? for mine was hard-hearted.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Hang her, she was some damn'd honest Person of Quality I'm sure, she was so very free and witty. If her face be but answerable to her Witt, and humour, I wou'd be bound to Constancy this Moneth to gain her—in the mean time, have you made no kind acquaintance since you came to Town?—you do not use to be honest so long, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Faith Love has kept us honest, we have been all fir'd with a Beauty newly come to Town, the Famous Paduana Angellica Bianca.a "Paduana" is someone who comes from the city of Padua. Many critics have noted that Angellica Bianca shares initials with Aphra Behn.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: What the Mistris of the dead Spanish General?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Yes, she's now the only ador'd Beauty of all the Youth in Naples, who put on all their Charms to appear lovely in her sight, their Coaches, Liveries, and themselves, all gay, as on a Monarch's Birth-Day, to attract the Eyes of this fair Charmer, while she has the pleasure to behold all languish for her that see her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis pretty to see with how much Love the Men regard her, and how much Envy the Women.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: What Gallant has she?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: None, she's expos'd to Sail, and Four days in the Week she's yours—for so much a Month.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: The very thought of it quenches all manner of Fire in me—yet prithee let's see her.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Let's first to Dinner, and after that wee'l pass the day as you please—but at Night yee must all be at my Devotion.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I will not fail you.

div.trailer: The End of the First Act.

div.head: Scene I. The Long Street.
div.stage: Enter Belvile and Frederick in Masquing Habits, and Willmore in his own Cloaths, with a Vizarda simple mask; pictures attatched at the following link: https://finds.org.uk/database/artefacts/record/id/402520 in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: But why thus disguis'd and muzzel'd?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Because whatever Extravagances we commit in these Faces, our own may not be oblig'd to answer 'em.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I shou'd have chang'd my Eternal Buffe too; but no matter, my little Gipsie wou'd not have found me out then; for if she shou'd change hers, it is impossible I should know her, unless I should hear her prattle.—A Pox on't, I cannot get her out of my Head: Pray Heaven, if ever I do see her again, she prove damnably ugly, that I may fortifie my self against her Tongue.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Have a care of Love, for o' my conscience she was not of a quality to give thee any hopes.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Pox on 'em, why do they draw a Man in then? She has play'd with my Heart so, that 'twill never lye still, till I have met with some kind Wench, that will play the Game out with me— Oh for my Arms full of soft, white, kind—Woman! such as I fancy Angelica.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: This is her House, if you were but in stock to get admittance; they have not din'd yet; I perceive the Picture is not out.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I long to see the Shadow of the fair Substance; a Man may gaze on that for nothing.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Coll. Thy Hand—and thine

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I have been an Ass, a deluded Fool, a very Coxcomb from my Birth till this hour, and heartily repent my little Faith.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: What the Devil's the matter with thee Ned?
—Oh such a Mrs.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: such a Girl!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Ha! where.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ay where!

sp.speaker: Blunt
sp.l:
So fond, so amorous, so toying and so fine! and all for sheer Love ye Rogue! Oh how she lookt and kist! and sooth'd my
Heart from my Bosom—I cannot think I was awake, and yet methinks I see and feel her charms still—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: —Try if she have not left the taste of her Balmey Kisses upon my Lips—

sp.speaker: Belv
sp.l: Ha! Ha! Ha!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Death Man where is she?

—What a Dog was I to stay in dull England so long,—How have I laught at the Coll. When he sigh'd for Love! but now the little Archer has reveng'd him! and by this one Dart, I can guess at all his joys, which then I took for Fancies, meer Dreams and Fables.—Well, I'm resolv'd to sell all in Essex, and plant here for ever.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: What a Blessing 'tis, thou hast a Mistris thou dar'st boast of; for I know thy Humour is, rather to have a proclaim'd Clap, than a secret Amour.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Dost know her Name?

sp.speaker: Bluns.
sp.l: Her Name? No, 'sheartlikins what care I for Names. —She's fair! young! brisk and kind! even to ravishment! and what a Pox care I for knowing her by any other Title.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Didst give her any thing?

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Give her!—Ha, ha, ha! whe she's a Person of Quality; —that's a good one, give her! 'sheartlikins dost think such Creatures are to be bought? Or are we provided for such a Purchase? give her quoth ye? Why she presented me with this Bracelet, for the Toy of a Diamond I us'd to wear: No, Gentlemen, Ned Blunt is not every Body—She expects me again to Night.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Egad that's well; we'll all go.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Not a Soul: No, Gentlemen, you are Wits; I am a dull Countrey Rogue, I.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Well, Sir, for all your Person of Quality, I shall be very glad to understand your Purse be secure; 'tis our whole Estate at present, which we are loth to hazard in one Bottomrisk in a single ship; come, Sir, unlade.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Take the necessary Trifle useless now to me, that am belov'd by such a Gentlewoman—'sheartlikins Money! Here take mine too.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No, keep that to be couzen'd, that we may laugh.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Couzen'd!—Death! wou'd I cou'd meet with one, that wou'd couzen me of all the Love I cou'd spare to Night.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Pox, 'tis some common Whore upon my life.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: A Whore!—yes with such Cloths! such Jewels! such a House! such Furniture, and so Attended! a Whore!

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Why yes Sir, they are Whores, tho' they'll neither entertain you with Drinking, Swearing, or Bawdry; are Whores in all those gay Cloths, and right Jewels, are Whores with those great Houses richly furnisht with Velvet Beds, Store of Plate, handsome Attendance, and fine Coaches, are Whores and Errant ones.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Pox on't, where do these fine Whores live?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Where no Rogues in Office Ecliped Constables, dare give 'em Laws, nor the Wine Inspir'd Bullies of the Town, break their Windows; yet they are Whores tho this Essex Calf believe 'em Persons of Quality.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: 'Sheartlikins, y'are all Fools, there are things about this Essex Calf, that shall take with the Ladies, beyond all your Witt and Parts—this Shape and Size Gentlemen are not to be despis'd— my Waste too tolerably long, with other inviting signs, that shall be nameless.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Egad I believe he may have met with some Person of Quality that may be kind to him.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Dost thou perceive any such tempting things about him, that shou'd make a fine Woman, and of Quality, pick him out from all Mankind, to throw away her Youth and Beauty upon, nay and her dear heart too!—no, no, Angellica has rais'd the Price too high.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: May she languish for Mankind till she dye, and be damn'd for that one sin alone.

div.stage: Enter Two Bravo's, and hang up a great Picture of Angellica's, against the Balcone, and Two little ones at each side of the Door.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: See there the fair Sign to the Inn where a Man may Lodg that's Fool enough to give her price.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: 'Sheartlikins, Gentlemen, what's this!

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: A Famous Courtizan, that's to be sold.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: How? to be sold! nay then I have nothing to say to her—sold! what Impudence is practic'd in this Countrey? —with what Order and decency Whoring's Establisht here by Virtue of the Inquisition—come let's begone, I'm sure wee're no Chapmen for this Commodity.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Thou art none I'm sure, unless thou coud'st have her in thy Bed at a price of a Coach in the Street.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: How wondrous fair she is—a Thousand Crowns a Month—by Heaven as many Kingdoms were too little, a plague of this Poverty—of which I ne're complain, but when it hinders my approach to Beauty: which Virtue ne're cou'd purchase.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: What's this?— [Reads.] A Thousand Crowns a Month!
—'Sheartlikins here's a Sum! sure 'tis a mistake.
—Heark you Friend, does she take or give so much by the Month?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: A Thousand Crowns! why 'tis a Portion for the Infanta.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Heark ye Friends, won't she trust?

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.l: This is a Trade, Sir, that cannot live by Credit.

div.stage: Enter Don Pedro in Masquerade, follow'd by Stephano.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: See, here's more Company, let's walk off a while.

div.stage: Enter Angellica and Moretta in the Balcone, and draw a Silk Curtain.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Fetch me a thousand Crowns, I never wisht to buy this Beauty at an easier rate.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Prithee what said those Fellows to thee?

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.l: Madam, the first were admirers of Beauty only, but no purchasers, they were merry with your Price and Picture, laught at the Sum, and so past off.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: No Matter, I'm not displeas'd with their rallying; their wonder feeds my vanity, and he that wishes but to buy, gives me more Pride, than he that gives my Price, can make my pleasure.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.l: Madam, the last I knew through all his disguises to be Don Pedro, Nephew to the General, and who was with him in Pampalona.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Don Pedro! my old Gallant's Nephew, when his Uncle dy'd he left him a vast Sum of Money; it is he who was so in love with me at Padua, and who us'd to make the General so Jealous.

sp.speaker: Morett.
sp.l: Is this he that us'd to prance before our Window, and take such care to shew himself an Amorous Ass? If I am not mistaken he is the likeliest Man to give your price.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: The Man is brave and generous, but of an humour so uneasie and inconstant, that the victory over his heart is as soon lost as won, a Slave that can add little to the Triumph of the Conquerour, but Inconstancy's the sin of all Mankind, therefore I'm resolv'd that nothing but Gold, shall charm my heart.

sp.speaker: Moret.
sp.l: I'm glad on't; 'tis only Interest that Women of our profession ought to consider: tho' I wonder what has kept you from that general Disease of our Sex so long, I mean that of being in Love.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: A kind, but sullen Star under which I had the happiness to be born; yet I have had no time for Love; the bravest and noblest of Mankind have purchast my favours at so dear a rate, as if no Coin but Gold were currant with our Trade— but here's Don Pedro again, fetch me my Lute—for 'tis for him or Don Antonio the Vice-Roys Son, that I have spread my Nets.

div.stage: Enter at one Door Don Pedro, Stephano; Don Antonio and Diego at the other Door with People following him in Masquerade, antickly attir'd, some with Musick, they both go up to the Picture.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A Thousand Crowns! had not the Painter flatter'd her, I shou'd not think it dear.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: Flatter'd her! by Heav'n he cannot, I have seen the Original, nor is there one Charm here more than Adorns her Face and Eyes; all this soft and sweet, with a certain languishing Air, that no Artist can represent.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What I heard of her Beauty before had fir'd my Soul, but this confirmation of it has blown it to a flame.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Sir, I have known you throw away a Thousand Crowns on a worse face, and tho y'are near your Marriage, you may venture a little Love here▪ Florinda will not miss it.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: Ha! Florinda!—sure 'tis Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Florinda! name not those distant joyes, there's not one thought of her will check my Passion here.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: Florinda scorn'd! and all my [A noise of a Lute above. hopes defeated, of the Possession of Angelica. [Ant. gazes up. Her Injuries! by Heaven he shall not boast of.

lg.l: WHen Damon first began to Love
He languisht in a soft desire,
And knew not how the Gods to move,
To lessen or increase his Fire.
For Caelia in her charming Eyes
Wore all Love's sweets, and all his cruelties.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: But as beneath a Shade he lay,
Weaving of Flow'rs for Caelia's hair,
She chanc't to lead her Flock that way,
And saw the Am'rous Shepherd there.
She gaz'd around upon the place,
And saw the Grove (resembling Night)
To all the joys of Love invite,
Whilst guilty smiles and blushes drest her Face.
At this the bashful Youth all Transport grew,
And with kind force he taught the Virgin how
To yield what all his sighs cou'd never do.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: By Heav'n she's charming fair!

div.stage: Angellica throws open the Curtains, and bows to Antonio, who pulls off his Vizard and bows and blows up kisses. Pedro unseen looks in's face.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: 'Tis he; the false Antonio!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Friend, where must I pay my Offring of Love?
My Thousand Crowns I mean.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: That Offring I have design'd to make.
And yours will come too late.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Prithee begone, I shall grow angry else.
And then thou art not safe.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: My Anger may be fatal, Sir, as yours;
And he that enters here may prove this truth.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I know not who thou art, but I am sure thou'rt worth my killing, for aiming at Angelica.

div.stage: Enter Willmore and Blunt, who draw and part 'em.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: 'Sheartlikins, here's fine doings.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Tilting for the Wench I'm sure—nay gad, if that wou'd win her, I have as good a Sword as the best of ye.—Put up,— put up, and take another time and place, for this is design'd for Lovers only.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: We are prevented; dare you meet me to Morrow on the Molo?
For I've a Title to a better quarrel,
That of Florinda in whose credulous heart
Thou'st, made an Int'rest, and destroyd my hopes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Dare!
I'll meet thee there as early as the day.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: We will come thus disguised, that whosoever chance to get the better, he may escape unkown.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It shall be so. [Ex. Pedro and Stephano. Who shou'd this Rival be? unless the English Colonel, of whom I've often heard Don Pedro speak; it must be he, and time he were remov'd, who lays a claim to all my happiness.

div.stage: Willmore having gaz'd all this while on the Picture, pulls down a little one.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: This Posture's loose and negligent,
The sight on't wou'd beget a warm desire,
In Souls whom Impotence and Age had chill'd.
—This must along with me.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.l: What means this rudeness, Sir?—restore the Picture.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ha! Rudeness committed to the fair Angellica!
—Restore the Picture, Sir—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Indeed I will not, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: By Heav'n but you shall.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Nay, do not shew your Sword, if you do, by this dear Beauty—I will shew mine too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What right can you pretend to't?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: That of Possession which I will maintain—you perhaps have a 1000 Crowns to give for the Original.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No matter, Sir, you shall restore the Picture.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Oh Moretta! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Or leave your life behind,

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Death! you lye—I will do neither.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Hold, I command you, if for me you Fight.

div.stage: They Fight, the Spaniards joyn with Ant. Blunt laying on like mad. They leave off and bow.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: How Heavenly fair she is!—ah Plague of her price.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: You Sir in Buffe, you that appear a Souldier, that first began this Insolence—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: 'Tis true, I did so, if you call it Insolence for a Man to preserve himself; I saw your Charming Picture and was wounded; quite through my Soul each pointed Beauty ran; and wanting a Thousand Crowns to procure my remedy—I laid this little Picture to my Bosom—which if you cannot allow me, I'll resign.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: No you may keep the Trifle.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You shall first ask me leave, and this.

div.stage: Enter Belv. and Fred. who joyn with the English.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Hold! will you ruine me!—Beskey—Sebestian— part'em.—

sp.speaker: Morett.
sp.l: Oh Madam, we're undone, a pox upon that rude Fellow, low, he's set on to ruine us: we shall never see good days, till all these fighting poor Rogues are sent to the Gallies.

div.stage: Enter Belvile, Blunt Fred. and Wilmour with's shirt bloody.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: 'Sheartlikins, beat me at this sport, and I'le ne're wear Sword more.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: The Devil's in thee for a mad Fellow, thou art always one, at an unluckey Adventure—come let's begon whil'st wee're safe, and remember these are Spaniards, a sort of People that know how to revenge an Affront.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You bleed! I hope you are not wounded.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Not much:—a plague on your Dons, if they fight no better they'l ne're recover Flanders.—what the Devil was't to them that I took down the Picture?

sp.speaker: Blunt.
Ang.
sp.l: Stay Sir, and e're you Affront me farther, let me know how you durst commit this out-rage—to you I speak Sir, for you appear a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: To me, Madam—Gentlemen your Servant.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Is the Devil in thee? do'st know the danger of entring the house of an incens'd Courtizan?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I thank you for your care—but there are other matters in hand, there are, tho we have no great Temptation—Death! let me go.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Yes to your Lodging if you will, but not in here.
—Damn these Gay Harlots—by this hand I'll have as sound and handsome a Whore, for a Patacoone,—death Man, she'll Murder thee.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Oh! fear me not, shall I not venture where a Beauty calls? a lovely Charming Beauty! for fear of danger! when by Heav'n there's none so great, as to long for her, whil'st I want Moto purchase her.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: Therefore 'tis loss of time unless you had the Thousand Crowns to pay.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: It may be she may give a Favour, at least I shall have the pleasure of Saluting her when I enter, and when I depart.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Pox, she'll as soon lye with thee, as kiss thee, and sooner stab than do either—you shall not go.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Fear not Sir, all I have to wound with is my Eyes.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Let him go, 'Sheartlikins, I believe the Gentlewoman means well.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Well take thy Fortune, we'll expect you in the next Street—farewell Fool—Farewell—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: 'Buy Colonel—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: The Rogue's stark mad for a Wench.

div.head: SCENE. A fine Chamber.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Insolent Sir, how durst you pull down my Picture?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l:
Rather, how durst you set it up, to tempt poor Am'rous▪ Mortals with so much excellence? which I find you have but too well consulted by the unmerciful price you set upon't.—
Is all this Heaven of Beauty shewn to move despair in those that cannot buy? and can you think th' effects of that despair, shou'd be less extravagant than I have shewn?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I sent for you to ask my Pardon Sir, not to Aggravate your Crime—I thought I shou'd have seen you at my Feet imploring it.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: You are deceiv'd, I came to rail at you, and rail such truths too, as shall let you see, the vanity of that Pride, which taught you how, to set such Price on Sin. For such it is, whil'st that which is Loves due. is meanly barter'd for.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Ha! ha! ha! alas good Captain, what pitty 'tis your edifying Doctrine will do no good upon me—Moretta! fetch the Gentleman a Glass, and let him surveigh himself. To see what Charms he has—and guess my business.

sp.speaker: Morett.
sp.l: He knows himself of Old, I believe those Breeches and he have been acquainted ever since he was beaten at Worcester.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Nay do not abuse the poor Creature—

sp.speaker: Morett.
sp.l: Good Weather beaten Corporal, will you march off? we have no need of your Doctrine, tho' you have of our Charity, but at present we have no scraps, we can afford no kindness for God's sake; in fine Sirrah, the price is too high 'ith Mouth for you, therefore Troop I say.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Here good Fore-Woman of the Shop serve me, and I'll be gone.

sp.speaker: Morett.
sp.l: Keep it to pay your Landress, your Linnen stinks of the Gun Room; for here's no selling by Retail.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Thou hast sold plenty of thy Stale. Ware at a Cheap rate.

sp.speaker: Morett.
sp.l: Ay the more Silly kind Heart I, but this is an Age wherein Beauty is at higher rates—In fine you know the price of this.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Igrant you 'tis here—set down a Thousand Crowns a Month—pray how much may come to my Share for a Pistol. —Bawd take your black Lead and Sum it up, that I may have a Pistols worth of this vain gay things, and I'll trouble you no more.

sp.speaker: Morett.
sp.l: Pox on him he'll fret me to death:—abominable Fellow, I tell thee, wee only sell by the whole piece.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l:
'Tis very hard, the whole Cargo or nothing—Faith
Madam, my Stock will not reach it, I cannot be your Chapman —Yet I have Country Men in Town, Merchants of Love like me; I'll see if they'll put in for a share, we cannot lose much by it, and what we have no use for, we'll sell upon the Frydays Mart at—Who gives more? I am studying Madam how to purchase you, tho' at present I am unprovided of Money.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Sure this from any other Man would anger me—nor shall he know the Conquest he has made—poor angry Man, how I despise this railing.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Yes, I am poor—but I'm a Gentleman,
And one that Scornes this basenessmembership or characteristic of a lower social class (OED)which you practice;
Poor as I am, I wou'd not sell my self,
No not to gain your Charming high priz'd Person.
Tho' I admire you strangely for your Beauty,
Yet I contemn your mind.
—And yet I wou'd at any rate enjoy you,
At your own rate—but cannot—see here
The only Sum I can command on Earth;
I know not where to eat when this is gon.
Yet such a Slave I am to Love and Beauty
This last reserve I'll sacrifice to enjoy you.
—Nay do not frown, I know you're to be bought,
And wou'd be bought by me, by me,
For a mean triffling sum if I cou'd pay it down
Which happy knowledge I will still repeat,
And lay it to my Heart, it has a Virtue in't,
And soon will cure those Wounds your Eyes have made.
—And yet—there's something so Divinely powerful there—
Nay I will gaze—to let you see my strength.
sp.stage: [Holds her, looks on her, and pawses and sighs.
sp.l: —By Heav'n bright Creature—I would not for the World
Thy Fame were half so fair, as is thy Face.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: His words go through me to the very Soul.
—If you have nothing else to say to me—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Yes, you shall hear how Infamous you are—
For which I do not hate thee—
But that secures my heart, and all the Flames it feels
Are but so many Lusts—
I know it by their sudden bold Intrusion.
The Fire's impatient and betrays, 'tis false—
For had it been the purer flame of Love,
I shou'd have pin'd and languisht at your feet,
E're found the impudence to have discover'd it.
I now dare stand your scorn, and your denyal.

sp.speaker: Monet.
sp.l: Sure she's bewitch, that she can stand thus tamely and hear his sawcy railing—Sirrah, will you be gon?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: How dare you take this Liberty?—withdraw. [To Mor. —Pray tell me, Sir, are not you guilty of the same Mercenary Crime,

When a Lady is propos'd to you for a Wife, you never ask, how fair—discreet—or virtuous she is; but what's her Fortune— which if but small, you cry—she will not do my business— and basely leave her, thou she languish for you—say, is not this as poor?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: It is Barbarous Custome, which I will scorn to defend in our Sex, and do despise in yours.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Thou'rt a brave Fellow! put up thy Gold, and know,
That were thy Fortune large as is thy Soul,
Thou shoud'st not buy my Love,
Coudst thou forget those mean effects of vanity
Which set me out to sale, and, as a Lover, prize my yielding joys.
Canst thou believe they'l be intirely thine,
Without considering they were Mercenary?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I cannot tell, I must bethink me first—ha—death I'm going to believe her.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Prithee confirm that faith—or if thou canst not— flatter me a little, 'twill please me from thy mouth.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Curse on thy charming Tongue! dost thou return
My feign'd contempt with so much subtilty?
Thou'st found the easiest way into my heart,
Tho I yet know, that all thou say'st is false.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: By all that's good 'tis real,
I never lov'd before, tho oftshortening of often (OED)a Mistress.
—Shall my first Vows be slighted?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: What can she mean?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I find you cannot credit me.—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I know you take me for an erranttravelling or roaming (OED)Ass,
An Ass that may be sooth'd into belief,
And then be us'd at pleasure;
—But, Madam, I have been so often cheated
By perjur'd soft deluding Hypocrites,
That I've no faith left for the couzeningalso spelled cozening, it means cheating, deceitful or fraudulent (OED)Sex;
Especially for Women of your Trade.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: The low esteem you have of me, perhaps
May bring my heart again:
For I have pride, that yet surmounts my Love.

div.stage: [She turns: with pride he holds her.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Throw off this Pride, this Enemy to Bliss,
And shew the Pow'r of Love: 'tis with those Arms
I can be only vanquisht, made a Slave.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Is all my mighty expectation vanisht?
—No, I will not hear thee talk—thou hast a Charm
In every word that draws my heart away.
And all the Thousand Trophies I design'd
Thou hast undone—Why art thou soft?
Thy looks are bravely rough, and meant for War.
Coud'st thou not storm on still?
I then perhaps had been as free as thou.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Death, how she throws her Fire about my Soul!
—Take heed, fair Creature, how you raise my hopes,
Which once assum'd pretends to all dominion.
There's not a joy thou hast in store,
I shall not then Command.
—For which I'll pay thee back my Soul! my Life!
—Come, let's begin th' account this happy minute!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: And will you pay me then the price I ask?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Oh why dost thou draw me from an awful Worship,
By shewing thou art no Divinity.
Conceal the Fiend, and shew me all the Angel!
Keep me but ignorant, and I'll be devout
And pay my Vows for ever at this shrine.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: The pay, I mean, is but thy Love for mine.
—Can you give that?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Intirely—come, let's withdraw! where I'll renew my Vows—and breath 'em with such Ardour thou shalt not doubt my zeal.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Thou hast a Pow'r too strong to be resisted.

sp.speaker: Moret.
sp.l: Now my Curse go with you—is all our Project fallen to this? to love the only Enemy to our Trade? nay, to love such a Shameroone, a very Beggar, nay a Pyrate Beggar, whose business is to rifle, and be gone, a no Purchase, no Pay Taterdemalion, and English Piccaroona pirate or privateer (OED).
A Rogue that fights for daily drink, and takes a Pride in being Loyally Lousie—Oh I cou'd curse now, if I durst.—This is the Fate of most Whores.

lg.l: Trophies, which from believing Fops we win,
Are Spoils to those who couzen us agen.

div.trailer: The End of the Second ACT.

div.head: Scene I. A Street.
div.stage: Enter Florinda, Valeria, Hellena, in Antickin dress or attire (OED)different Dresses, from what they were in before--antick has a specific sense too. Callis attending.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I Wonder what shou'd make my Brother in so ill a humour? I hope he has not found out our Ramble this Morning.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: No, if he had, we shou'd have heard on't at both Ears, and have been Mew'din hiding or a place of confinement, like a cage (OED)up this Afternoon; which I wou'd not for the World shou'd have hapned—hey ho, I'm as sad as a Lover's Lute.—

sp.speaker: Vall▪
sp.l:
Well, methinks we have learnt this Trade of Gipsies as readily, as if we had been bred upon the Road to Loretta: and yet I did so fumble, when I told the stranger his Fortune, that I was
afraid I should have told my own and yours by mistake—but, methinks Hellena has been very serious ever since.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I wou'd give my Garters she were in Love, to be reveng'd upon her, for abusing me—how is't, Hellena?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Ah—wou'd I had never seen my mad Monsieur—and yet for all your laughing, I am not in Love—and yet this small acquaintance o' my Conscience will never out of my head.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha—I laugh to think how thou art fitted with a Lover, a fellow that I warrant loves every new Face he sees.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Hum—he has not kept his word with me here—and may be taken up—that thought is not very pleasant to me— what the Deuce shou'd this be now, that I feel?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What is't like?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Nay, the Lord knows—but if I shou'd be hang'd, I cannot choose, but be angry and afraid, when I think, that mad Fellow shou'd be in Love with any Body but me—what to think of my self, I know not—wou'd I cou'd meet with some true damn'd Gipsie, that I might know my Fortune.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Know it! why there's nothing so easie, thou wilt love this wandring Inconstant, till thou findst thy self hang'd about his Neck, and then be as mad to get free again.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Yes, Valeria, we shall see her bestride his Baggage Horse, and follow him to the Campaigne.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: So, so, now you are provided for, there's no care taken of poor me—but since you have set my heart a wishing—I am resolv'd to know for what, I will not dye of the Pip, so I will not.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Art thou mad to talk so? who will like thee well enough to have thee, that, hears what a mad Wench thou art?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Like me! I don't intend every he that likes me shall have me, but he that I like; I shou'd have staid in the Nunnery still, if I had lik'd my Lady Abbesse as well as she lik'd me—no, I came thence not (as my wise Brother imagines) to take an Eternal Farewel of the World, but to Love, and to be belov'd, and I will be belov'd, or I'll get one of your Men, so I will.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Am I put into the number of Lovers?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l:
You? why Couz, I know thou'rt too good natur'd to leave us in any design: thou wou't venture a Cast, tho thou comest off a loser, especially with such a Gamester.—I observe your Man, and your willing Ear incline that way; and if you are not
a Lover, 'tis an Art soon learnt—that I find.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I wonder how you learnt to Love so easily, I had a 1000 Charms to meet my Eyes and Ears, e're I cou'd yield, and 'twas the knowedge of Belvile's merit, not the surprizing Person took my Soul—thou art too rash to give a heart at first sight.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Hang your considering Lover; I never thought beyond the fancy that 'twas a very pretty, idle, silly, kind of pleasure to pass ones time with, to write little soft. Nonsensical Billiets, and with great difficulty and danger receive Answers; in which I shall have my Beauty prais'd, my Wit admir'd, (tho little or none) and have the vanity and pow'r to know I am desirable; then I have the more inclination that way, because I am to be a Nun, and so shall not be suspected to have any such Earthly thoughts about me—but when I walk thus—and sigh thus— they'l think my mind's upon my Monastery, and cry how happy 'tis she's so resolv'd.
—But not word of Man.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: What a mad Creature's this?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: I'll warrant, if my Brother hears either of you sigh, he cryes (gravely)—I fear you have the indiscretion to be in Love, but take heed of the Honour of our House, and your own unspotted Fame, and so he Conjures on till he has laid the soft wing'd God in your Hearts, or broke the Birds Nest—but see here comes your Lover, but where's my Inconstant? let's step aside, and wee may learn something.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: What means this! the Picture's taken in.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: It may be the Wench is good Natur'd, and will be kind Gratis. Your Friend's a proper handsome Fellow.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: I rather think she has cut his Throat and is fled: I am mad he shou'd throw himself into dangers—pox on't I shall want him too at Night—let's knock and ask for him.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: My Heart goes a pit, a pat, for fear 'tis my Man they talk off.

sp.speaker: Morett.
sp.l: What wou'd you have!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Tell the stranger that enter'd here about two hours agoe, that his Friends stay here for him.

sp.speaker: Morett.
sp.l: A Curse upon him for Moretta, wou'd he were at the Devil—but he's coming to you.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: I, I, 'tis he! Oh how this vexes me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: And how and how dear Lad, has Fortune smil'd! are we to break her Windows! or raise up Alters to her. hah!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Does not my Fortune sit Triumphant on my Brow! dost not see the little wantonOf a person, a person's will: undisciplined, ungoverned; unmanageable, rebellious (OED) God there all gay and smiling. Have I not an Air about my Face and Eyes, that distinguish me from the Crow'd of common Lovers! By Heav'n Cupids Quiver has not half so many Darts as her Eyes!—Oh such a Bona RobaA wench (OED)! to sleep in her Arms is lying in Fresco, all perfum'd Air about me.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Here's fine encouragement for me to fool on.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Hark'ey where didst thou purchase that rich Canary we drank to day! tell me that I may Adore the SpigotA small wooden peg or pin used to stop the vent-hole of a barrel or cask; a vent-peg; a similar peg inserted into and controlling the opening or tube of a faucet and used to regulate the flow of liquor (OED), and Sacrifice to the Butt! the Juice was Divine! into which I must dip my Rosary, and then bless all things that I would have bold or Fortunate.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Well Sir, let's go take a Bottle, and hear the story of your Success.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Wou'd not French Wine do better.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Damn the hungry BalderdashJumbled mixture of liquors e.g. beer and wine, chearful SackA general name for a class of white wines formerly imported from Spain and the Canaries (OED) has a generous Virtue in't inspiring a successful confidence, gives Eloquence to the Tongne! and vigour to the Soul! and has in a few hours compleated all my hopes and wishes! There's nothing left to raise a new desire in me—come let's be gay and wanton—and Gentlemen study, study what you want, for here are Friends,—that will supply Gentlemen,—heark! what a Charming sound they make—'tis he and the Gold whil'st here, and shall beget new pleasures every Moment.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: But heark'ey Sir, you are not Marryed are you?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: All the honey of Matrimony, but none of the sting Friend.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: 'Sheartlikins thou'rt a Fortunate Rogue!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I am so Sir, let these—inform you!—ha how sweetly they Chime!—pox of Poverty it makes a Man a slave, makes Wit and Honour sneak, my Soul grew lean and rusty for want of credit.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: 'Sheartlikins this I like well, it looks like my lucky Bargain! Oh how I long for the approach of my Squire, that is to conduct me to her House again whe—here's two provided for.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: By this light y' are happy Men.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Fortune is pleas'd to smile on us Gentlemen—to smile on us.

div.stage: Enter Sancho and pulls down Blunt by the sleeve.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.l: Sir my Lady expects [They go aside. you—she has remov'd all that might oppose your will and pleasure—and is impatient till you come.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Sir I'll attend you—oh the happiest Rogue! I'll take no leave, least they either dog me, or stay me.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: But then the little Gipsie is forgot?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: A mischief on thee for putting her into my thoughts I had quite forgot her else, and this Nights debauch had drunk her quite down.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Had it so good Captain!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Hah! I hope she did not hear me.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: What afraid of such a Champion?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Oh! you're a fine Lady of your word, are you not? to make a Man languish a whole day—▪

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: In tedious search of me.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Egad Child thou'rt in the right, had'st thou seen what a Melancholy Dog I have been ever since I was a Lover, how I have walkt the streets like a CapuchinA friar of the order of St. Francis, of the new rule of 1528 (OED) with my Hands in my Sleeves—Faith sweet Heart thou would'st pitty me.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Now if I shou'd be hang'd I can't be angry with him he dissembles so Heartily—alas good Captain what pains you have taken—now were I ungrateful not to reward so true a Servant.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Poor Soul! that's kindly said, I see thou barest a Conscience —come then for a beginning shew me thy dear Face.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: I'm afraid, my small acquaintance, you have been staying that swinging Stomach you boasted of this Morning; I then remember my little CollationBringing together, comparison (OED) wou'd have gone down with you, without the Sauce of a handsome Face—is your Stomach so queasiy now?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Faith long fasting Child, spoils a Mans Appetite—yet if you durst treat, I cou'd so lay about me still—

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: And wou'd you fall to, before a Priest says Grace?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Oh 〈◊〉 , what an Old out of fashion'd thing hast thou nam'd? thou cou'st not dash me more out of Countenance shoud'st thou shew me an ugly Face.

div.stage: Enter Angellica Moretta Biskey and Sebastian all in Masquerade, Ang. sees Will. and stares.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Heavens 'ts he! and passionately fond to see another Woman.

sp.speaker: Morett.
sp.l: What cou'd you less expect from such a swaggerer?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Expect! as much as I paid him, a Heart intire
Which I had Pride enough to think when 'ere I gave,
It would have rais'd the Man above the Vulgar
Made him all Soul! and that all soft and constant.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: You see Captain, how willing I am to be Friends with you, till time and ill luck make us Lovers, and ask you the Question first, rather then put your Modesty to the blush, by asking me (for alas!) I know you Captains are such strict Men and such severe observers of your Vows to Chastity, that 'twill be hard to prevail with your tender Conscience to Marry a young willing Maid.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Do not abuse me, for fear I shou'd take thee at thy word, and Marry thee indeed, which I'm sure will be revenge sufficient.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: O' my Conscience, that will be our Destiny, because we are both of one humour; I am as inconstant as you, for I have consider'd, Captain, that a handsome Woman has a great deal to do whilst her Face is good, for then is our Harvest-time to gather Friends; and should I in these dayes of my Youth, catch a fit of foolish Constancy, I were undone; 'tis loitering by day-light in our great Journey: therefore I declare, I'll allow but one year for Love, one year for indifference, and one year for hate— and then—go hang your self—for I profess my self the gay, the kind, and the Inconstant—the Devil's in't if this won't please you.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Oh most damnably—I have a heart with a hole quite through it too, no Prison mine to keep a Mistress in.

sp.speaker: Ang.
