sp.l: Perjur'dOf a person that has deliberately broken an oath (OED) Man! how I believe thee now.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Well, I see our business as well as humours are a like, yours to couzen as many Maids as will trust you, and I as many Men as have Faith—see if I have not as desperate a lying look, as you can have for the heart of you.
—How do you like it Captain?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Like it! by Heav'n, I never saw so much beauty! Oh the Charms of those sprightly black Eyes! that strangely fair Face! full of smiles and dimples! those soft round melting Cherry Lips! and small even white Teeth! not to be exprest, but silently ador'd!—oh one look more! and strike me dumb, or I shall repeat nothing else till I'm mad.

div.stage: [He seems to Court her to pull off her VizarThe front part of a helmet, covering the face but provided with holes or openings to admit of seeing and breathing, and capable of being raised and lowered;(OED): she refuses.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I can endure no more—nor is it fit to interrupt him, for if I do, my Jealousie has so destroid my Reason,—I shall undo him —therefore I'l retire—and you, Sebastian, [To one of her Bravo's. follow that Woman, and learn who 'tis; while you tell the Fugitive, I wou'd speak to him instantly.

div.stage: This while Flor. is talking to Belvile, who stands sullenly. Fred. courting Valeria.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Prithee, dear stranger, be not so sullen, for tho you have lost your Love, you see my Friend franckly offers you hers to play with in the mean time.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Faith Madam, I am sorry I can't play at her Game.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Pray leave your IntercessionThe action of interceding or pleading on behalf of (rarely against),(OED), and mind your own Affair, they'l better agree apart; he's a modest sigherTo emit, give, or heave a sigh(OED) in Company, but alone no Woman scapes him.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Sure he does but rally—yet if it shou'd be true— I'll tempt him farther—believe me, Noble Stranger, I'm no common Mistris—and for a little proof on't—wear this JewelAn article of value used for adornment, chiefly of the person / possibly a picture of her (OED)—nay, take it, Sir, 'tis right, and Bills of Exchange may sometimes miscarry.Phrase meant to suggest that a promise or vow to be "paid" can be counterfeited or easily passed from one to another (O'Brien in class / wikipedia)

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Madam, why am I chose out of all Mankind to be the Object of your Bounty?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: There's another civil Question askt.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Pox of's Modesty, it spoils his own Markets & hinders mine.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Sir, from my Window I have often seen you, and Women of my Quality have so few opportunities for Love, that we ought to loose none.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ay, this is something! here's a Woman!—when shall I be blest with so much kindness from your fair Mouth?—take the Jewel, Fool.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: You tempt me strangely Madam every way—

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: So, if I find him false, my whole ReposeTemporary rest or cessation from physical or mental exertion in order to recover one's energy (OED)

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: And but for a Vow I've made to a very Lady, this goodness had subdu'd me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Pox on't be kind, in pitty to me be kind, for I am to thrive here but as you treat her Friend.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Tell me what you did in yonder House, and I'll unmasque.unmask

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Yonder House—oh—I went to—a—to—why there's a Friend of mine lives there.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: What a Shee, or a Hee Friend?she and he respectively

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: A Man upon Honour! a Man—a Shee Friend—no, no Madam you have done my business I thank you.his womanizing has ended with her

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: And wast your Man Friend, that had more Darts in's Eyes, than Cupid carries in's whole BudgetA pouch, bag, wallet, usually of leather. (OED) of Arrowes.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: So—

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Ah such a Bona Roba!Italian for: A wench; ‘a showy wanton’ (OED) to be in her Arms is lying in Fresco, all perfum'd Air about me—was this your Man Friend too?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: So—

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: That gave you the He, and the She Gold, that begets young pleasures?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Well, well Madam, then you see there are Ladies in the World, that will not be cruel—there are Madam there are—

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: And there be Men too, as fine, wild Inconstant Fellowes as your self, there be Captain there be, if you go to that now— therefore I'm resolv'd—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Oh!—

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: To see your Face no more—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Till to morrow.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Egad you frighted me.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Nor then neither, unless you'll swear never to see that Lady more.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: See her!—whe why (http://www.bookwolf.com/Wolf/pdf/AphraBehn-TheRover.pdf) never to think of Woman kind again.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Kneel,—and swear—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I do never to think—to see—to Love—nor Lye—sleep with with any but thy self.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Kiss the Book.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Oh most Religiously.refers to taking an oath on the bible / Oath: A solemn or formal declaration invoking God (or a god, or other object of reverence) as witness to the truth of a statement, or to the binding nature of a promise or undertaking (OED)

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Now what a wicked Creature am I, to damn a proper Fellow.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: Madam, I'll stay no longer, 'tis e'ne dark.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l:
How ever Sir, I'll leave this with you—that when
I'm gone, you may repent the opportunity you have lost, by your Modesty.

div.stage: Gives him the Jewel which is her Picture, and Ex. he gazes after her.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: 'Twill be an Agea long time / A period of existence, and related senses.(OED) till to Morrow,—and till then I will most impatiently expect you—Adieu my Dear pretty Angell.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Ha! Florinda's Picture—'twas she her self—what a dullDull: Not quick in intelligence or mental perception; slow of understanding; not sharp of wit(OED) Dog was I? I wou'd have given the World for one minuts discourse with her—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: This comes of your modesty!—ah poxSenses relating to diseases characterized by pocks(OED). Referencing a sort of curse on his vow o' your vow, 'twas ten to one, but we had lost the Jewel by't.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Willmore! the blessed'st opportunity lost! Florinda! Friends! Florinda!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Ah Rogue! such black Eyes! such a Face! such a Mouth! such Teeth—and so much Witt!—

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: All, all, and a Thousand Charmes besides.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Why dost thou know her?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Know her! Ay, Ay, and a pox take me with all my Heart for being Modest.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: But hearkey "hark ye"= (ref:http://www.bookwolf.com/Wolf/pdf/AphraBehn-TheRover.pdf). To give ear or listen to. (OED) Friend of mine, are you my Rival? and have I been only beating the Bushhe thinks he has chased his lady into the arms of another man. To rouse the birds that they may fly into the net held by some one else(OED) all this while?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: I understand thee not—I'm mad—see here—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Ha! whose Picture's this!—'tis a fine Wench!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: The Colonels Mrs. Sir.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Oh oh here—I thought 'thad been another prize— come, come, a Bottle will set thee right again.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: I am content to try, and by that time 'twill be late enough for our design.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Agreed.
Love does all day the Soules great Empire keep,
But Wine at night Lulls the soft God asleep.metaphor to understand and subdue loves troubling nature by drinking one's self to sleep

div.head: SCENE the II. Lucetta's House.
div.stage: Enter Blunt and Lucetta with a Light.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l:
Now we are safe and free; no fears of the coming home of my Old Jealous Husband, which made me a little thoughtful
when you came in first—but now Love is all the business of my Soul.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: I am transported!—pox on't, that I had but some fine things to say to her, such as Lovers use,—I was a Fool not to learn of Fred. a little by heart before I came—something I must say— [Aside. 'Sheartlikins sweet Soul! I am not us'd to Complement, but I'm an honest Gentleman, and thy humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I have nothing to pay for so great a Favour, but such a Love as cannot but be great, since at first sight of that sweet Face and Shape, it made me your absolute Captive.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Kind heart! how prettily she talks! Egad I'll shew her Husband a Spanish trick; send him out of the World and Marry her: she's damnably in Love with me, and will ne're mind Settlements, and so there's that sav'd.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Well Sir, I'll go and undress me, and be with you instantly.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Make hast then, for adshartilikins dear Soul thou canst not guess at the pain of a longing Lover; when his joys are drawn within the compass of a few Minuts.his plan to sleep with her is near completion. Compass: To plan, contrive, devise (OED). Also: navigational reference meaning close in proximity: A compass divided into 360 degrees is the most common unit of measurement. Each degree is divided into 60 minutes, each minute into 60 seconds...those units are used for precise locations using latitude and longitude.(http://www.compassdude.com/compass-units.php)

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You speak my sense, and I'l make hast to prove it.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: 'Tis a rare Girl! and this one Nights enjoyment with her, will be worth all the days I ever past in Essex.—wou'd she wou'd go with me into England; tho' to say truth there's plenty of Whores already.—But a Pox on 'em they are such Mercenary —Prodigal Whores, that they want such a one as this, that's Free and Generous to give 'em good Examples—Whewhy what a house she has, how rich and fine!

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.l: Sir, my Lady has sent me to conduct you to her Chamber.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Sir, I shall be proud to follow—here's one of her Servants too! 'Sheartlikins by this garb and gravity, he might be a Justice of Peace in Essex,addressing his clothes, in England he could be "A magistrate appointed to hear minor cases, grant licences, etc" (OED) and is but a Pimp here.

div.stage: The Scene Changes to a Chamber with an Alcove Bed in't, a Table, &c. Lucetta in Bed. Enter Sancho and Blunt, who takes the Candle of Sancho at the Door.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.l: Sir, my Commissionhis job or orders; Authority committed or entrusted to a person (OED) reaches no farther.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Sir I'll excuse your Complement—what in Bed my sweet Mistress.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You see, I still outdo you in kindness.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: And thou shalt see what haste I'll make to quit scores —oh the luckiest Rogue!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Shou'd you be false or cruel now!—

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: False! 'Sheartlikins, what dost thou take me for? A Jew? an insensible heathen—a Pox of thy Old Jealous Husband, an he were dead, Egad, sweet Soul, it shou'd be none of my fault, if I did not Marry thee.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It never shou'd be mine.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Good Soul! I'm the fortunatest Dog!luckiest rogue

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Are you not undrest yet?

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: As much as my impatience will permit.

div.stage: [Goes towards the Bed in his shirt, Drawers.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Hold, Sir, put out the Light, it may betray us else.darkness necessary to setup the robbery of Blunt

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Any thing, I need no other Light, but that of thine Eyes!—'Sheartlikins, there I think I had it. [Puts out the Candle, the Bed descends, he groaps about to find it. —Whe—whe—where am I got? what not yet?—where are you sweetest?—ah, the Rogue's silent now—a pretty Love trick this—how she'l laugh at me anon!in a short time; soon (CollinsDictionary)—you need not, my dear Rogue! you need not!—I'm all on fire already—come, come, now call me in pity.—Sure I'm Enchanted! I have been round the Chamber, and can find neither Woman, nor Bed—I lockt the Door, I'm sure she cannot go that way— or if she cou'd, the Bed cou'd not—Enough, enough, my pretty wanton, do not carry the jesttrick; an exploit(OED) too far—ha, Betrayed! Dogs! Rogues! Pimps!—help! help!

div.stage: [Lights on a Trap, and is let down.
Enter Lucetta, Phillippo, and Sancho with a Light.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, he's dispatch finely.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Now, Sir, had I been Coyanimal trap (OED), if she had been trapped by Blunt's love we had mist of this Booty.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Nay, when I saw 'twas a substantial Fool, I was mollified;That has been mollified; appeased, conciliated; †softened, rendered soft or supple; †made less severe; mitigated (OED). but when you dote upon a Serenading Coxcomb, upon a Face, fine Cloaths, and a LuteA stringed musical instrument, much in vogue from the 14th to the 17th centuries.(OED), it makes me rage.

sp.speaker: Luc.
Phill.
sp.l:
A rich Coat!—Sword and Hat—these Breechesshort pants / Breeches are distinguished from trousers by coming only just below the knee (OED) too—are well lin'd—see here, a Gold Watch!—The first actual pocket watch was "said to have occurred in 1675 when Charles II of England introduced waistcoats (Wikipedia).This would have been an incredibly exepensive item.
a Purse—ha!—Gold!—at least Two Hundred Pistols! —a bunch of Diamond Rings! and one with the Family Arms!—a Gold Box!—with a Medal of his King! and his Lady Mother's Picture!—these were Sacred Relics, believe me!—see, the Wasteband of his Breeches have a Mine of Gold!—Old Queen Besse'srefers to Queen Elizabeth I, reigned from 1558-1603.The quarrel from "Eighty Eight" seems to refer to the Spanish Armada, which was destroyed in 1588, we have a quarrel to her ever since Eighty Eight, and may therefore justify the Theft, the Inquisition might have committed it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: —See, a Bracelet of bowd Gold! these his Sisters tied about his Arm at parting—but well—for all this, I fear his being a Stranger, may make a noise and hinder our Trade with them hereafter.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: That's our security; he is not only a Stranger to us, but to the Country too—the Common ShoarSeems to refer to a sewer into which he entered into which he is descended, thou knowst conducts him into another Street, which this Light will hinder him from ever finding again—he knows neither your Name, nor that of the Street where you House is, nay nor the way to his own Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And art not thou an unmerciful Rogue! not to afford him one Night for all this?—I shou'd not have been such a Jew.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Blame me not, Lucetta, to keep as much of thee as I can to my self—come, that thought makes me wanton!—let's to Bed!—Sancho, lock up these.

lg.l: This is the Fleece which Fools do bear,
Design'd for witty Men to sheer.

div.stage: The Scene changes, and discovers Blunt, creeping out of a Common-Shoar, his Face, &c. all dirty.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l:
Oh Lord! [Climbing up. I am got out at last, and (which is a Miracle) without a Clue— and now to Damning and Cursing!—but if that wou'd ease me, where shall I begin? with my Fortune, my self, or the Queen that couzen'd me—what a Dog was I to believe in Woman? oh Coxcomb!—Ignorant conceited Coxcomb! to fancy she could be enamoured with my Person! at first sight enamoured! —oh, I'm a cursed Puppy! 'tis plain, Fool was writ upon my Forehead! she perceiv'd it!—saw the Essex-Calf there—
for what Allurements cou'd there be in this Countenance? which I can indure, because I'm acquainted with it—oh, dull silly Dog! to be thus sooth'd into a Couzening! had I been drunk, I might fondly have credited the young Quean!—but as I was in my right Wits, to be thus cheated, confirms it I am a dull believing English Country Fop—but my Camrades! death and the Devil! there's the worst of all—then a Ballad will be Sung to Morrow on the Prado, to a Lousie Tune of the Enchanted 'Squire, and the Annihilated Damsel—but Fred. that Rogue! and the Colonel, will abuse me beyond all Christian patience— had she left me my Clothes, I have a Bill of Exchange at home, would have saved my Credit—but now all hope is taken from me—well, I'l home (if I can find the way) with this Consolation, that I am not the first kind believing Coxcomb; but there are Gallants many such good Natures amongst ye.
And tho you've better Arts to hide your Follies,
Adsheartlikins y' are all as errant Cullies.

div.head: SCENE, the Garden in the Night.
div.stage: Enter Florinda in an undress, with a Key and a little Box.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Well, thus far I'm in my way to happiness; I have got my self free from Callis; my Brother too I find by yonder light is got into his Cabinet, and thinks not of me; I have by good Fortune, got the Key of the Garden back-door.—I'll open it to prevent Belvile's knocking—a little noise will now Alarm my Brother. Now am I as fearful as a young Thief. [Unlocks the door. —heark—what noise is that—oh, 'twas the Wind that played amongst the Boughs—Belvile stays long, methinks —it's time—stay—for fear of a surprise—I'll hide these Jewels in yonder Jessamin.

div.stage: [She goes to lay down the Box.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l:
What the Devil is become of these fellows, Belvile and Frederick, they promised to stay at the next Corner for me, but who the Devil knows the Corner of a Full Moon—now—where-abouts am I!—hah—what have we here a Garden!— a very convenient place to sleep in—hah—what has God
sent us here!—a Female!—by this Light a Woman!— I'm a Dog if it be not a very Wench!—

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: He's come!—hah—who's there?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Sweet Soul! let me salute thy Shoe-string.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: 'Tis not my Belvile.—good Heavens! I know him not —who are you, and from whence come you?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Prithee—prithee Child—not so many hard questions— let it suffice I am here Child—come, come kiss me.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Good Gods! what luck is mine?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l:
Only good luck Child, parlous good luck—come hither, —'tis a delicate shining Wench—by this hand she's perfumed, and smells like any NosegayA bunch of flowers or herbs, especially those having a sweet smell-OED—prithee dear Soul, let's not play the Fool, and lose time—precious time—for as God shall save me I'm as honest a Fellow as breathes, tho' I'm a little disguised at present—come I say—whe thou may'st be free with me, I'll be very secret. I'll not boast who 'twas obliged me, not I—for
hang me if I know thy name.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Heavens! what a filthy Beast is this?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I am so, and thou ought'st the sooner to lie with me for that reason—for look you Child, there will be no sin in't, because 'twas neither designed nor premeditated. 'Tis pure Accident on both sides—that's a certain thing now—indeed should I make Love to you, and you vow fidelity—and swear and lie till you believed and yielded—that were to make it wilful Fornication —the crying Sin of the Nation—thou art therefore (as thou art a good Christian) obliged in Conscience to deny me nothing. Now—come be kind without any more idle prating.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Oh I am ruined—Wicked Man unhand me.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Wicked!—Egad Child a Judge were he young and vigorous, and saw those Eyes of thine, would know 'twas they gave the first blow—the first provocation—come prithee let's lose no time, I say—this is a fine convenient place.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Sir, let me go, I conjure you, or I'll call out.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Ay, Ay, you were best to call Witness to see how finely you treat me—do—

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I'll cry Murder! Rape! or anything! if you do not instantly let me go.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l:
A Rape! Come, come, you lie you Baggage, you lie, what, I'll warrant you would fain have the World believe now that you are not so forward as I. No, not you—why at this time
of Night was your Cobweb Door set open dear Spider—but to catch Flies?—Hah—come—or I shall be damnably angry. —Whe what a CoylA noise or disturbance, a 'row', a tumult is here—

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Sir, can you think—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: That you would do't for nothing—oh, oh I find what you would be at—look here, here's a Pistol for you—here's a work indeed—here—take it I say—

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: For Heavens sake Sir, as you're a Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: So—now—now—she would be wheadling me for more —what, you will not take it then—you are resolved you will not—come—come take it, or I'll put if up again—for look ye, I never give more—whe how now Mistress, are you so high i'th' Mouth a Pistol won't down with you—hah—whe what a works' here—in good time—come, no struggling to be gone—but an y'are good at a dumb Wrestle I'm for ye—look ye—I'm for yee—

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: The Door is open, a pox of this mad Fellow, I'm angry that we've lost him, I durst have sworn he had followed us.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: But you were so hasty Colonel to be gone.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Help! help!—Murder!—help—oh I am ruined.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Ha! sure that's Florindas voyce.
—A Man! Villain let go that Lady.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Belvile! Heavens! my Brother too is coming, and 'twill be impossible to escape—Belvile I conjure you to walk under my Chamber Window, from whence I'll give you some Instructions what to do—this rude Man has undone us.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Belvile!

div.stage: Enter Pedro, Stephano, and other Servants with Lights.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I'm betrayed! run Stephano and see if Florinda be safe? [Ex. Steph.oSo, who e're they be, all is not well, I'll to Florindas Chamber.

div.stage: They Fight, and Ped. Party beats 'em out.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.l: You need not Sir, the poor Lady's fast asleep and thinks no harm. I would not awake her Sir, for fear of frighting her with your danger.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: I'm glad she's there—Rascals how came the Garden Door open?

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.l: That Question comes too late Sir, some of my Fellow Servants Masquerading I'le warrant.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Masquerading! a lewd Custome to debauch our youth, —there's something more in this then I imagine.

div.stage: Enter Belvile in Rage. Fred. holding him, and Wilmore Melancholy.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Whe how the Devil shou'd I know Florinda?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Ah plague of your Ignorance! if it had not been Florinda, must you be a Beast?—a Brute? a Senseless Swine.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Well Sir, you see I am endu'dimbued or transfused with patience—I can bear —tho Egad y'are very free with me, methinks.—I was in good hopes the Quarrel wou'd have been on my side, for so uncivilly interrupting me.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Peace Brute! whilst thou'rt safe—oh I'm distracted.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Nay, nay, I'm an unlucky Dogg, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Ah Curse upon the Star that Rul'd my Birth! or whatsoever other Influence that makes me still so wretched.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Thou break'st my Heart with these complaints; there is no Star in fault, no Influence, but Sack, the cursed Sack I drunk.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Whe how the Devil came you so drunk?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Whe how the Devil came you so sober?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: A Curse upon his thin Skullreference to the common law of taking your victim as you find them http://definitions.uslegal.com/t/thin-skull-rule/, he was always before hand that way.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Prithee Dear Colonel forgive him, he's sorry for his Fault.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: He's always so after he has done a mischief—a plague on all such Brutes.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: By this Light I took her for an Errant Harlot.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Damn your debaucht opinion! tell me Sot had'st thou so much sense and light about thee to distinguish her Woman, and coud st not see something about her Face and Person, to strike an awful Reverence into thy Soul?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Faith no, I consider'd her as meer a Woman as I cou'd wish.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: 'Sdeath, I have no patience—draw, or I'll kill you.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Let that alone till to Morrow, and if I set not all right again, use your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: To Morrow! damn it
The Spightful Light will lead me to no happiness.
To Morrow is Antonio's, and perhaps
Guides him to my undoing;—oh that I cou'd meet
This Rival! this pow'rfull Fortunate!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Let thy own Reason, or my Rage instruct thee.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I shall be finely inform'd then, no doubt, hear me Colonel —hear me—shew me the Man and I'le do his Business.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: I know him no more than thou, or if I did I shou'd not need thy Aid.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: This you say is Angellicas House, I promis'd the kind Baggage to lye with her to Night.

div.stage: Enter Antonio and his Page. Ant. knock on the Hilt of's Sword.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You paid the Thousand Crowns I directed?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: To the Ladies Old Woman, Sir I did.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Who the Devil have we here!

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: I'll now plant my self under Florinda's Window, and if I find no comfort there, I'll dye.

sp.speaker: Moret.
sp.l: Page!

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Here's my Lord.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: How is this! a PickrooneA variant spelling of Picaroon meaning a rogue or a scoundrel going to board my Fregatea warship? here's one Chase Guna canon at the bow or stern of an armed ship used in pursuit (Merriam-Webster) for you.

div.stage: Drawing his Sword, justlesjostles (Dictionary.com) Ant. who turns and draws. They fight, Ant. falls.

sp.speaker: Moret.
sp.l: Oh bless us! we're all undone!

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Help! Murder!

div.stage: [Belvile returns at the noise of fighting.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Ha! the mad Rogue's engag'd in some unlucky Adventure again.

sp.speaker: Masq.
sp.l: Ha! a Man kill'd!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: How! a Man kill'd! then I'l go home to sleep.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Who shou'd it be! pray Heaven the Rogue is safe for all my Quarrel to him.

div.stage: [As Belvile is groping about, Enter an Officer and six Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Offic.
sp.l: So, here's one dispatcht—secure the Murderer.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Do not mistake my Charity for Murder! I came to his Assistance.

sp.speaker: Offic.
sp.l: That shall be try'd, Sir—St. Iago, Swords drawn in the Carnival time!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thy hand prithee.

sp.speaker: Offic.
sp.l: Ha! Don Antonio! look well to the Villain there.— How is it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'm hurt.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Has my humanity made me a Criminal?

sp.speaker: Offic.
sp.l: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: What a curst chance is this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This is the Man, that has set upon me twice—carry him to my Appartment, till you have farther Orders from me.

div.trailer: The End of the Third ACT.

div.head: Scene I. A fine Room.
div.stage: Discovers Belvile as by dark alone.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l:
VVHen shall I be weary of railing on Fortune, who is resolv'd never to turn with smiles upon me —Two such defeats in one Night—none but the Devil, and that mad Rogue cou'd have contriv'd to have plagu'd me with
—I am here a Prisoner—but where—Heav'n knows —and if there be Murder done, I can soon decide the Fate of a Stranger in a Nation without mercy—yet this is nothing to the Torture my Soul bows with, when I think of losing my fair, my dear Florinda—heark—my door opens—a Light— a Man—and seems of Quality—arm'd too!—now shall I dye like a Dog without defence.

div.stage: Enter Antonio in a Night-Gown, with a Light; his Arm in a Scarf, and a Sword under his Arm: he sets the Candle on the Table.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir, I come to know what Injuries I have done you, that cou'd provoke you to so mean an Action, as to Attack me basely, without allowing time for my defence?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Sir, for a Man in my circumstances to plead Innocence, wou'd look like fear—but view me well, and you will find no marks of Coward on me; nor any thing that betrays that Brutality you accuse me with.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: In vain, Sir, you impose upon my sense.
You are not only he who drew on me last Night,
But yesterday before the same house, that of Angellica.
Yet there is something in your Face and Meine
That makes me wish I were mistaken.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: I own I fought to day in the defence of a Friend of mine, with whom you (if you're the same) and your Party were first engag'd.
Perhaps you think this Crime enough to kill me,
But if you do; I cannot fear you'l do it basely.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No, Sir, I'l make you fit for a defence with this.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: This Gallantry surprizes me—nor know I how to use this Present, Sir, against a Man so brave.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You shall not need;
For know, I come to snatch you from a danger
That is decreed against you:
Perhaps your Life, or long Imprisonment;
And 'twas with so much Courage you offended,
I cannot see you punisht.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: How shall I pay this Generosity?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It had been safer to have kill'd another
Than have attempted me:
To shew your danger, Sir, I'l let you know my Quality;
And 'tis the Vice-Roy's Son, whom you have wounded.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: The Vice-Roy's Son!
Death and Confusion! was this Plague reserv'd
To compleat all the rest—oblig'd by him!
The Man of all the World I wou'd destroy.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You seem disorder'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Yes, trust me, Sir, I am, and 'tis with pain
That Man receives such Bounties,
who wants the Pow'r to pay 'em back again▪

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To gallant Spirits 'tis indeed uneasie;
—But you may quickly over pay me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Then I am well—kind Heav'n! but set us even,
That I may fight with him and keep my Honour safe.
—Oh, I'm impatient, Sir, to be discounting
The mighty Debt I owe you, Command me quickly—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have a Quarrel with a Rival, Sir,
About the Maid we love.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Death, 'tis Florinda he means—
That thought destroys my Reason,
And I shall kill him—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My Rival, Sir,
Is one has all the Virtues Man can boast of—

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Death! who shou'd this be?
He challeng'd me to meet him on the Molo,
As soon as day appear'd, but last Nights quarrel,
Has made my Arm unfit to guide a Sword.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: I apprehend you, Sir, you'd have me kill the Man,
That lays a Claim to the Maid you speak of.
—I'l do't—I'l fly to do't!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir, do you know her?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: —No, Sir, but 'tis enough she is admir'd by you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir, I shall rob you of the Glory on't,
For you must fight under my Name and Dress.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: That Opinion must be strangely obliging that makes
You think I can personate the brave Antonio,
Whom I can but strive to imitate.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You say too much to my Advantage;
—Come, Sir, the day appears that calls you forth.
—Within, Sir, is the habit.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Fantastick Fortune, thou deceitful Light,
That Cheats the wearied Traveller by Night,
Tho on a Precipice each step you tread,
I am resolv'd to follow where you lead.

div.head: SCENE, the Mole.
div.stage: Enter Florinda and Callis in Masques with Stephano.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I'm dying with my fears, Belvile's not coming as I expected under my Window,
Makes me believe that all those fears are true.
—Canst thou not tell with whom my Brother fights?

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.l: No, Madam, they were both in Masquerade, I was by when they challeng'd one another, and they had decided the Quarrel then, but were prevented by some Cavaliers; which made 'em put it off till now—but I am sure 'tis about you they fight.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Nay, then 'tis with Belvile, for what other Lover have I that dares fight for me, except Antonio? and he is too much in favour with my Brother—if it be he, for whom shall I direct my Prayers to Heav'n?

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.l: Madam, I must leave you, for if my Master see me, I shall be hang'd for being your Conductor—escapt narrowly for the excuse I made for you last Night i'th Garden.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: And I'l reward thee for't—prithee no more.

div.stage: Enter Don Pedro in his Masquing Habit.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: Antonio's late to day, the place will fill, and we may be prevented.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Antonio sure I heard amiss.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: But who will not excuse a happy Lover
When soft fair Arms confine the yielding Neck;
And the kind whisper languishingly breathes.
—Must you begone so soon?—
Sure I had dwelt for ever on her Bosome.
—But stay, he's here.

div.stage: Enter Belvile drest in Antonio's Clothes.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: 'Tis not Belvile, half my fears are vanisht.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: Antonio!

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: This must be he.
You're early, Sir,—I do not use to be out-done this way.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: The wretched, Sir, are watchful, and 'tis enough
You've the advantage of me in Angellica.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Angellica! or I've mistook my Man! or else Antonio.
—Can he forget his Intrest in Florinda,
And fight for common Prize?

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: Come, Sir, you know our terms—

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: By Heav'n not I.
—No talking, I am ready, Sir.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Oh, hold! who e're you be, I do conjure you hold!
If you strike here—I dye—

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: Florinda!

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Florinda imploring for my Rival!

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: Away, this kindness is unseasonable.

div.stage: [Puts her by, they fight; she runs in just as Belv. disarms Pedro.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Who are you, Sir, that dares deny my Prayers?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Thy Prayers destroy him, if thou would'st preserve him,
Do that thou'rt unacquainted with and Curse him.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: By all you hold most dear, by her you love,
I do conjure you, touch him not.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: By her I love!
See—I obey—and at your feet resign
The useless Trophy of my Victory.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: Antonio, you've done enough to prove you love Florinda.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Love Florinda!
Does Heav'n love Adoration! Pray'r! or Penitence! Love her! here, Sir,—your Sword again. [Snatches up the Sword and gives it him. Upon this truth I'l fight my life away.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: No, you've redeem'd my Sister, and my Friendship!

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Don Pedro!

div.stage: He gives him Flor. and pulls off his Vizard to shew his Face and puts it on again.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: Can you resign your Claims to other Women,
And give your heart intirely to Florinda?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Intire! as dying Saints Confessions are!
I can delay my happiness no longer.
This Minute! let me make Florinda mine.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: This Minute let it be—no time so proper,
This Night my Father will arrive from Rome,
And possibly may hinder what wee purpose!

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Oh Heavens! this Minute!

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Oh, do not ruine me!

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: The place begins to fill, and that we may not be observ'd, do you walk off to St. Peters Church, where I will meet you, and conclude your happiness.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: I'll meet you there.—If there be no more Saints Churches in Naples.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Oh stay Sir, and recal your hasty doom!
alas I have not yet prepar'd my Heart
To entertain so strange a Guest.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: Away this silly modesty is Assum'd too late.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Heaven Madam! what do you do?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Do! despise the Man that lays a Tyrant's Claim
To what he ought to Conquer by submission.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: You do not know me—move a little this way.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Yes, you may force me even to the Alter,
But not the holy Man that offers there
Shall force me to be thine.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Oh do not loose so blest an opportunity!
—See—'tis your Belvile—not Antonio,
Whom your mistaken Scorn & Anger ruines.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Belvile.
Where was my Soul it cou'd not meet thy Voyce!
And take this knowledge in.

div.stage: As they are talking, Enter Wilmore finely drest, and Frederick.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: No Intelligence! no News of Belvile yet—well I am the most unlucky Rascal in Nature—ha—am I deceiv'd —or is it he—look Ferd.—'tis he—my dear Belvile.

div.stage: Runs and Embraces him. Belv. Vizard falls out on's Hand.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Hell and confusion seize thee!

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: Ha! Belvile! I beg your Pardon Sir.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Nay touch her not, she's mine by Conquest Sir,
I won her by my Sword.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Did'st thou so—and Egad Child wee'l keep her by the Sword.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Stand off
Thou'rt so profanely Lewd, so curst by Heaven,
All quarrels thou espousest must be Fatal.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Nay an you be so hot, my Valour's Coy, and shall be Courted when you want it next.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: You know I ought to Claim a Victors right.
But you're the Brother to Divine Florinda,
To whom I'm such a Slave—to purchase her,
I durst not hurt the Man she holds so dear.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: 'Twas by Antonio's, not by Belvile's Sword
This question should have been decided Sir,
I must confess much to your Bravery's due,
Both now, and when I met you last in Arms.
But I am nicely punctual in my word,
As Men of Honour ought, and beg your Pardon.
—For this mistake another time shall clear.
—This was some Plot between you and Belvile.
But I'll prevent you.

div.stage: Aside to Flor. as they are going out Belv. looks after her and begins to walk up and down in Rage.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Do not be Modest now and loose the Woman, but if wee shall fetch her back so—

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Do not speak to me—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Not speak to you—Egad I'll speak to you, and will be answer'd too.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Will you Sir—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I know I've done some mischief, but I'm so dull a Puppey, that I'm the Son of a Whore, if I know how, or where— prithee inform my understanding—

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Leave me I say, and leave me instantly.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I will not leave you in this humour, nor till I know my Crime.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Death I'll tell you Sir—

div.stage: Draws and runs at Will. he runs out, Belv. after him, Fred. interposes.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Ha—Sebastian—
Is not that Willmore?—hast—hast and bring him back.

sp.speaker: Fred'
sp.l: The Colonel's mad—I never saw him thus before, I'l after 'em least he do some mischief, for I am sure Wilmore will not draw on him.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I am all Rage! my first desires defeated!
For one for ought he knows that has no
Other Merit than her Quality.
—Her being Don Pedro's Sister—he loves her!
I know 'tis so—dull, dull, Insensible—
He will not see me now tho oft invited;
And broke his word last Night—false perjur'dOf a person: that has committed or is guilty of perjury; that has deliberately broken an oath, promise, etc. (OED) Man!
—He that but Yesterday fought for my Favours,
And wou'd have made his Life a Sacrifice
To've gain'd one Night with me,
Must now be hir'd and Courted to my Arms.

sp.speaker: Morett.
sp.l: I told you what wou'd come ou't, but Moretta's an old doating Fool—why did you give him five Hundred Crowns, but to set himself out for other Lovers! you shou'd have kept him Poor, if you had meant to have had any good from him.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Oh, name not such mean trifles;—had I given him all
My Youth has earn'd from Sin,
I had not lost a thought, nor sigh upon't.
But I have given him my Eternal rest,
My whole repose, my future joys, my Heart!
My Virgin heart Moretta! Oh 'tis gone!

sp.speaker: Morett.
sp.l: Curse on him here he comes;
How fine she has made him too.

div.stage: Enter Willmore and Sebast. Ang. turns and walks away.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: How now turn'd shaddow!
Fly when I pursue! and follow when I fly!
Stay gentle shadow of my Dove
And tell me e're I go,
Whether the substance may not prove
A Fleeting thing like you.
There's a soft kind look remaining yet.

div.stage: As she turns she looks on him.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Well Sir, you may be gay, all happiness, all joyes pursue you still, Fortune's your Slave, and gives you every hour choyce of new hearts and Beauties, till you are cloy'd Clogged, cumbered, burdened (OED) with the repeated Bliss, which others vainly languish for.—
—But know false Man that I shall be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: So gad there are of those faint hearted Lovers, whom such a sharp Lesson next their hearts, wou'd make as Impotent as Fourscore—pox o' this whining.—My bus'ness is to laugh and love—a pox on't, I hate your sullen Lover, a Man shall lose as much time to put you in humour now, as wou'd serve to gain a new Woman.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I scorn to cool that Fire I cannot raise,
Or do the Drudgery of your virtuous Mistris.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: A virtuous Mistress! death, what a thing thou hast found out for me! why what the Devil, shou'd I do with a virtuous Woman? —a sort of ill-natur'd Creatures, that take a Pride to torment a Lover, Virtue is but an infirmity in Woman; a Disease that renders even the handsome ungrateful; whilst the ill-favour'd for want of Solicitations and Address, only fancy themselves so.—I have layn with a Woman of Quality, who has all the while been railing at Whores.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I will not answer for your Mistres's Virtue,
Though she be Young enough to know no Guilt;
And I cou'd wish you wou'd perswade my heart
'Twas the Two hundred Thousand Crowns you Courted.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Two Hundred Thousand Crowns! what Story's this? —what Trick?—what Woman?—ha!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: How strange you make it, have you forgot the Creature you entertain'd on the Prazo last Night?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Ha! my Gipsie worth Two Hundred Thousand Crowns! —oh how I long to be with her—pox, I knew she was of Quality.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: False Man! I see my ruine in thy face.
How many Vows you breath'd upon my Bosome,
Never to be unjust—have you forgot so soon?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Faith no, I was just coming to repeat 'em—but here's a humour indeed—wou'd make a Man a Saint—wou'd she wou'd be angry enough to leave me, and Command me not to wait on her.

div.stage: Enter Hellena drest in Man's Cloths.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: This must be Angellica! I know it by her mumpingTo utter indistinctly or inarticulately, as if with toothless gums; to mumble, mutter (OED) Matron here—Ay, ay, 'tis she! my Mad Captain's with her too, for all his swearing—how this unconstant humour makes me love him!—Pray good grave Gentle woman is not this Angellica?

sp.speaker: Moret.
sp.l: My too young Sir, it is—I hope 'tis one from Don Antonio.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Well, something I'l do to vex him for this.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I will not speak with him; am I in humour to receive a Lover.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Not speak with him! whe I'l begon—and wait your idler Minutes—can I shew less obedience to the thing I love so fondly?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: A fine excuse, this!—stay—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: And hinder your advantage! shou'd I repay your Bounties so ungratefully?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Come hither, Boy—that I may let you see
How much adove the advanges you name
I prize one Minutes joy with you.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Oh, you destroy me with this indearment. [Impatient to be gone. —Death! how shall I get away—Madam, 'twill not be fit I shou'd be seen with you—besides, it will not be convenient —and I've a Friend—that's dangerously sick.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I see you're impatient—yet you shall stay.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: And miss my Assignation with my Gipsie.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Madam,
sp.stage: Moretta brings Hellena, who addresses her self to Angellica.
sp.l: You'l hardly pardon my Intrusion,
When you shall know my business!
And I'm too young to tell my Tale with Art:
But there must be a wondrous store of goodness,
Where so much Beauty dwells.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: A pretty Advocate whoever sent thee.
—Prithee proceed—Nay, Sir, you shall not go.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Then I shall lose my dear Gipsie for ever
—Pox on't, she stays me out of spight.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I am related to a Lady, Madam,
Young, Rich, and nobly born, but has the Fate
To be in Love with a young English Gentleman.
Strangely she loves him, at first sight she lov'd him,
But did Adore him when she heard him speak;
For he, she said, had Charms in every word,
That faild not to surprize, to Wound and Conquer.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Ha! Egad I hope this concerns me.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: 'Tis my false man, he means—wou'd he were gone.
This Praise will raise his Pride, and ruin me—well
Since you are so impatient to be gon
I will release you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Nay, then I'm sure 'twas me he spoke off, this cannot be the effects of kindness in her.
—No, Madam, I've consider'd better on't,
And will not give you Cause of Jealousie.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: But, Sir, I've—bus'ness, that—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: This shall not do, I know 'tis but to try me.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Well, to your story, Boy,—tho 'twill undo me.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: With this addition to his other Beauties,
He won her unresisting tender heart,
He vow'd, and sigh't, and swore he lov'd her dearly;
And she believ'd the cunning flatterer,
And thought her self the happiest Maid alive,
To day was the appointed time by both
To consummate their Bliss,
The Virgin, Altar, and the Priest were drest,
And whilst she languisht for th' expected Bridegroom,
She heard, he paid his broken Vows to you.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: So, this is some dear Rogue that's in Love with me,
And this way lets me know it; or if it be not me, she means some one whose place I may supply.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Now I perceive
The cause of thy impatience to be gone,
And all the business of this Glorious Dress.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Damn the young Prater, I know not what he means.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Madam,
In your fair Eyes I read too much concern,
To tell my farther business.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Prithee, sweet Youth, talk on, thou maist perhaps
Raise here a storm that may undo my passion,
And then I'l grant thee any thing.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Madam, 'tis to intreat you, (oh unreasonable)
You wou'd not see this stranger;
For if you do, she Vows you are undone,
Tho Nature never made a Man so Excellent,
And sure he'ad been a God, but for inconstancy.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Ah, Rogue, how finely he's instructed!
—'Tis plain; some woman that has seen me e'n passant.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Oh, I shall burst with Jealousie! do you know the Man you speak off?—

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Yes, Madam, he us'd to be in Buff and Scarlet.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Thou, false as Hell, what canst thou say to this?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: By Heaven—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Hold, do not Damn thy self—

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Nor hope to be believ'd.—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Oh perjur'd Man!
Is't thus you pay my generous Passion back?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Why wou'd you, Sir, abuse my Lady's Faith?—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: And use me so unhumanely.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: A Maid so young, so innocent—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Ah, young Divel.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Dost thou not know thy life is my pow'r?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Or think my Lady cannot be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: So, so, the storm comes finely on.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Now thou art silent, guilt has struck thee dumb.
Oh, hadst thou still been so, I'd liv'd in safety.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Sweet heart, the Lady's Name and House,—quickly: I'm impatient to be with her.—

div.stage: Aside to Hellena, looks towards Angell. to watch her turning, and as she comes towards them he meets her.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: So, now is he for another Woman.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: The impudents young thing in nature,
I cannot perswade him out of his Error, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I know he's in the right,—yet thou'st a tongue
That wou'd perswade him to deny his Faith.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Her Name, her Name, dear Boy.—

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Have you forgot it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Oh, I perceive he's not to know I am a stranger to his Lady.
—Yes, yes I do know—but—I have forgot the—
—By Heaven such early confidence I never saw.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Did I not charge you with this Mistris, Sir?
Which you deny'd, tho' I beheld your, Perjury.
This little generosity of thine, has render'd back my heart.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: So, you have made sweet work here, my little mischief;
Look your Lady be kind and good natur'd now, or
I shall have but a Cursed Bargain on't.
—The Rogue's bred up to mischief,
Art thou so great a Fool to credit him?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Yes, I do, and you in vain impose upon me.
—Come hither, Boy,—is not this he you spake of.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: I think—it is, I cannot swear, but I vow he has just such another lying Lovers look.

div.stage: [Hell. looks in his face, he gazes on her.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Hah! do not I know that face—
By Heaven my little Gipsie, what a dull Dog was I,
Had I but lookt that way I'd known her.
Are all my hopes of a new Woman banisht?
—Egad if I do not fit thee for this, hang me.
—Madam, I have found out the Plot.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Oh Lord, what does he say? am I discover'd now?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Do you see this young Spark here?—

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: He'l tell her who I am.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: —Who do you think this is?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Ay, ay, he does know me—Nay, dear Captain! I am undone if you discover me.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Nay, nay, no eogging, she shall know what a pretious Mistris I have.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Will you be such a Devil?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l:
Nay, nay, I'l teach you to spoil sport you will not make.
— this small Ambassador comes not from a Person of Quality as you Imagine, and he says: but from a very Errant Gipsie, the talking'st, prating'st, canting'st little Animal thou ever saw'st.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: What news you tell me, that's the thing I mean.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Wou'd I were well off the place, if ever I go a Captain, Hunting again— Aside

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Mean that thing? that Gipsie thing, thou may'st as well be Jealous of thy Monkey or Parrot, as of her, a German Motion were worth a duzen of her, and a Dream were a better enjoyment, a Creature of a Constitution fitter for Heaven then Man.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Tho I'm sure he lyes, yet this vexes me. Aside.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: You are mistaken, she's a Spanish Woman Made up of no such dull Materials.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Materials, Egad an shee be made of any that will either dispence or admit of Love, I'le be bound to continence.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Unreasonable Man, do you think so? Aside to him. — you may return my little Brazen Head, and tell your Lady, that till she be handsom enough to be belov'd, or I dull enough to be Religious, there will be small hopes of me.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Did you not promise then to marry her?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Not I by heaven.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: You cannot undeceive my fears and torments, till you have vow'd you will not marry her.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: If he Swears, that he'le be reveng'd on me indeed for all my Rogueries. Aside.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I know what Arguments you'll bring against me, Fortune, and Honour.—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Honour, I tell you, I hate it in your Sex, and those that fancy themselves possest of that Foppery, are the most impertinently troublesome of all Woman kind, and will transgress Nine Commandments to keep one, and to satisfie your Jealousie I swear.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Oh, no swearing dear Captain. Aside to him.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: If it were possible, I should ever be inclin'd to marry, it shou'd be some kind young Sinner, one that has generosity, enough to give a favour hansomely to one that can ask it discreetly, one that has Witt enough to Manage an intrigue of Love—oh, how civil such a Wench is, to a Man that does her the Honour to marry her.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: By Heaven there's no Faith in any thing he says.

sp.speaker: Sebas.
sp.l: Madam, Don Antonio—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Come hither.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Ha! Antonio, he may be coming hither and he'l certainly discover me, I'le therefore retire without a Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I'le see him, get my Coach ready.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.l: It waits you Madam,

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: This is luckey: what Madam, now I may be gone and leave you to the injoyment of my Rival?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Dull man, that can'st not see how Ill, how poor,
That false dissimulation looks—begon
And never let me see thy Couzening Face again,
Least I relaps and kill thee.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Yes, you can spare me now,—farewel, till you're in better Humour—I'm glad of this release—
Now for my Gipsie:
For tho' to worse we change, yet still we find
New Joys, new Charms, in a New Miss that's kind.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: He's gone, and in this Ague of my Soul
The Shivering fit returns;
Oh with what willing haste, he took his leave,
As if the long'd-for Minute, were arriv'd
Of some blest assignation.
In vain I have Consulted all my Charms,
In vain this Beauty priz'd, in vain believ'd,
My Eyes cou'd kindle any lasting fires;
I had forgot my Name, my Infamie,
And the reproach that Honour lays on those
That dare pretend a sober passion here.
Nice reputation, tho' it leave behind
More Vertues than inhabit where that dwells;
Yet that once gone, those Vertues shine no more.
—Then since I am not fit to be belov'd,
I am resolv'd to think on a revenge
On him that sooth'd me thus to my undoing.

div.head: SCENE the Third. A Street.
div.stage: Enter Florinda and Valeria in Habits different from what they have been seen in.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: We're happily Escap't, and yet I tremble still.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A Lover and fear! whe I am but half an one, and yet I have Courage for any attempt, wou'd Hellena were here , I wou'd fain have had her as deep in this Mischief as we, she'le fare but in else I doubt.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: She pretended a Visit to the Augustine Nuns, but I believe some other design carried her out, pray Heaven we light on her.—Prithee what did'st do with Callis?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: When I saw no reason wou'd do good on her, I follow'd her into the Wardrobe, and as she was looking for something in a great Chest, I topled her in by the heels, snatch't the Key of the Appartment where you were confin'd, lock't her in, and left her bawling for help.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: 'Tis well you resolve to follow my Fortunes, for thou darest never appear at home again after such an action.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That's according as the young Stranger and I shall agree. —but to our bus'ness—I deliver'd your Letter, your Note to Belvile, when I got out under pretence of going to Mass, I found him at his Lodging, and believe me it came seasonably; for never was Man in so desperate a Condition, I told him of your resolution of making your Escape to day, if your Brother would be absent long enough to permit you; if not,to die rather than be Antonio's.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Thou should'st have told him I was confin'd to my Chamber upon my Brothers suspition, that the bus'ness on the Molo was a Plott laid between him and I.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I said all this, and told him your Brother was now gone to his Devotion, and he resolves to visit every Church till he find him; and not only undeceive him in that, but carress him so as shall delay his return home.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Oh Heavens! he's here, and Belvile with him too.

div.stage: Enter Don Pedro, Belvile, Willmore. Bel.and Don Pedro seeming in serious discourse.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Walk boldly by them, and I'le come at distance, least he suspect us.
sp.stage: She walks by them, and looks back on them.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Hah! a Woman, and of an Excellent Mien.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: She throws a kind look back on you.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Death, tis a likely Wench, and that kind look shall not be cast away—I'le follow her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Prithee do not.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Do not, by Heavens to the Antipodies, with such an invitation.

div.stage: [She goes out, and Will. follows her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: 'Tis a mad Fellow for a Wench.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Oh Col. such News!

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Prithee what?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: News that will make you laugh in spight of Fortune.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What, Blunt has had some Damn'd Trick put upon him, Cheated, Bang'd or Clapt.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Cheated Sir, rarely Cheated of all but his Shirt &Drawers, the unconscionable Whore too turn'd him out before Consummation, so that traversing the Streets at Midnight, the Watch found him in this Fresco, and conducted him home: By Heaven 'tis such a sight, and yet I durst as well been hang'd as laught at him, or pity him; he beats all that do but ask him a question, and is in such an Humour.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Who is't has met with this Ill usage, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: A Friend of ours whom you must see for mirths sake. I'le imploy him to give Florinda time for an escape.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: What is he?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: A Young Countryman of ours, one that has been Educated at so plentiful a rate, he yet ne're knew the want of Money, and 'twill be a great Jeast to see how simply he'le look without it, for my part I'le lend him none, and the Rogue know not how to put on a Borrowing face, and ask first, I'le let him see how good 'tis to play our parts whilst I play his—prithee Fred. do you go home and keep him in that posture till we come.

div.stage: Enter Florinda from the farther end of the Scene, looking behind ber.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I am follow'd still—hah.—my Brother too advancing this way, good Heavens defend me from being seen by him.

div.stage: Enter Willmore, and after him Valeria, at a little distance.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Ah! There she sailes, she looks back as she were willing to be boarded, I'le warrant her Prize.

div.stage: Enter Hellena, just as he goes out, with a Page:

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Hah, is not that my Captain that has a Woman in chase? —'tis not Angellica; Boy, follow those people at a distance, and bring me an account where they go in,—I'le find his haunts, and plague him every where,—ha—my Brother—

div.stage: [Bel. Wil. Ped. cross the Stage: Hell. runs off.
Scene changes to another Street. Enter Florinda.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: What shall I do, my Brother now pursues me,

Will no kind Pow'r protect me from his tyranny? —hah, here's a door open, I'le venture in, since nothing can be worse then to fall into his hands, my life and honour are at stake, and my Necessity has no choyce.

div.stage: Enter Valeria and Hellena's Page peeping after Florinda.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Here she went in, I shall remember this house.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This is Belvil's Lodging; she's gone in as readily as if she knew it,—hah—here's that Mad Fellow again, I dare not venture in,—I'le watch my opportunity.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I have lost her hereabouts—Pox on't, she must not scape me so.

div.stage: Scene changes to Blunts Chamber, discovers him sitting on a Couch in his Shirt and Drawers, reading.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l:
So, now my mind's a little at peace, since I have resolv'd revenge—a Pox on this Tayler tho, for not bringing home the Clothes I bespoke; and a Pox of all poor Cavaliers, a Man can never keep a spare Suit for 'em; and I shall have these Rogues come in and find me naked, and then I'm undone; but I'm resolv'd to arm my self—the Rascals shall not insult over me too much. [Puts on an old rusty Sword, and Buff Belt. —Now, how like a Morrice-Dancer I am Equipt—a fine
Lady like Whore to Cheat me thus, without affording me a kindness for my Money, a Pox light on her, I shall never be reconcil'd to the Sex more, she has made me as faithless as a Phisitian, as uncharitable as a Church-man, and as ill natur'd as a Poet. Oh how I'l use all woman-kind hereafter! what wou'd I give to have one of 'em within my reach now! any Mortal thing in Petticoats, kind Fortune, send me! and I'l forgive thy last nights Malice—here's a Cursed Book too, (a warning to all young Travellers) that can instruct me how to prevent such Mischiefs now 'tis too late, well 'tis a rare convenient thing to read a little now and then, as well as Hawk and Hunt.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: This House is haunted sure, 'tis well furnisht and no living thing inhabits it—hah—a Man, Heavens how he's attir'd! sure 'tis some Rope-dancer, or Fencing-master; I tremble now for fear, and yet I must venture now to speak to him—Sir, if I may not interrupt your Meditations—

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Hah—what's here! are my wishes granted? and is not that a she Creature? ads heartlikins 'tis! what wretched thing art thou—hah!

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: And must be ruin'd, if you do not grant it.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Ruin'd! is there any ruin so inevitable as that which now threatens thee? dost thou know, miserable Woman! into what Den of Mischiefs thou art fall'n? what abiss of Confusion— hah!—dost not see something in my looks that frights thy guilty Soul, and makes thee wish to change that shape of Woman for any humble Animal, or Devil? for those were safer for thee, and less mischievous.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Alas, what mean you, Sir? I must confess, your looks have something in 'em, makes me fear, but I beseech you, as you seem a Gentleman, pity a harmless Virgin, that takes your house for Sanctuary.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l:
Talk on, talk on, and weep too, till my Faith-return Do, flatter me out of my Senses again—a harmless Virgin
with a Pox, as much one as 'tother, adsheartlikins. Whe what the Devil can I not be safe in my House for you, not in my Chamber, nay, even being naked too cannot secure me: this is an Impudence greater than has invaded me yet—Come, no resistance.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Dare you be so cruel?

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l:
Cruel, adsheartlikins as a Galley slave, or a Spanish▪
Whore: Cruel, yes I will kiss and beat thee all over; kiss, and see thee all over; thou shalt lye with me too, not that I care for the injoyment, but to let thee see I have tain deliberated Malice to thee, and will be reveng'd on one Whore for the sins of another; I will smile and deceive thee, flatter thee, and beat thee, kiss and swear, and lye to thee, imbrace thee and rob thee, as she did me, fawn on thee, and strip thee stark naked; then hang thee out at my window by the heels, with a Paper of scurvy Verses fasten'd to thy breast, in praise of damnable women—Come come along.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Alas, Sir, must I be sacrific'd for the Crimes of the most infamous of my Sex, I never understood the fins you name.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Do, perswade the Fool you Love him, or that one of you can be just or honest, tell me I was not an easie Coxcomb, or any strange impossible tale: it will be believ'd sooner than thy false Showres or Protestations. A generation of damn'd Hypocrites to flatter my very Clothes from my Back! dissembling Witches! are these the returns you make an honest Gentleman, that trusts, believes, and loves you—but if I be not even with you—Come along—or I shall—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Hah! what's here to do?

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Adsheartlikins, Fred. I am glad thou art come, to be a witness of my dire revenge.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What's this, a Person of Quality too, who is upon the ramble to supply the defects of some grave impotent Husband?

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l:
No, this has another pretence, some very unfortunate accident, brought her hither, to save a life pursu'd by I know not who, or why, and forc't to take sanctuary here at Fools Haven. Adsheartlikins to me of all Mankind for protection? is the Ass to be Cajold again, think ye? No, young one, no Prayers or Tears shall mitigate my rage; therefore prepare for both my
pleasures of injoyment and revenge, for I am resolv'd to make up my loss here on thy body, I'l take it out in kindness and in beating.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Now Mistress of mine, what do you think of this?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I think he will not—dares not be so barbarous.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Have a care, Blunt, she fetch't a deep sigh, she is inamour'd with thy Shirt and Drawers, she'l strip thee even of that, there are of her calling such unconscionable Baggages, and such dexterous Thieves, they'l flea a man and he shall ne're miss his skin, till he feels the cold. There was a Country-man of ours Rob'd of a Row of Teeth whilst he was a sleeping, which the Jilt made him buy again when he wak't—you see Lady how little reason we have to trust you.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: 'Dsheartlikins, whe this is most abominable.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Some such Devils there may be, but by all that's Holy, I am none such, I enter'd here to save a Life in danger.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: For no goodness, I'l warrant her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Faith, Damsel, you had e'en confest the plain truth, for we are fellows not to be caught twice in the same Trap: look on that Wreck, a tite Vessel when he set out of Haven, well Trim'd and Laden, and see how a Female Piccaroon of this Island of Rogues has shatter'd him, and canst thou hope for any Mercy?

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: No, no, Gentlewoman, come along, adsheartlikins we must be better acquainted—we'l both lye with her, and then let me alone to bang her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I'm ready to serve you in matters of Revenge that has a double pleasure in't.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Well said. You hear, little one, how you are condemn'd by publick Vote to the Bed within, there's no resisting your Destiny, sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Stay, Sir, I have seen you with Belvile, an English Cavalier, for his sake use me kindly; you know him, Sir.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Belvile, whe yes, sweeting, we do know Belvile, and wish he were with us now, he's a Cormorant at Whore and Bacon, he'd have a Limb or two of thee my Virgin Pullet, but 'tis no matter, we'l leave him the bones to pick.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Sir, if you have any Esteem for that Belvile, I conjure you to treat me with more gentleness; he'l thank you for the justice.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Harkey, Blunt, I doubt we are mistaken in this Matter.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Sir, if you find me not worth Belvile's care, use me as you please, and that you may think I merit better treatment than you threaten—pray take this present—

div.stage: [Gives him a Ring: he loods on it.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Hum—a Diamond! whe 'tis a wonderful Virtue now that lies in this Ring, a mollifying Virtue; adsheartlikins there's more perswasive Rhetorick in't, than all her Sex can utter.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I begin to suspect something; and 'twould anger us vilely to be trust up for a rape upon a Maid of quality, when we only believe we ruffle a Harlot.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Thou art a credulous Fellow, but adsheartlikins I have no Faith yet, whe my Saint prattled as parlously as this does, she gave me a Bracelet too, a Devil on her, but I sent my Man to fell it to day for Necessaries, and it prov'd as counterfeit as her Vows of Love.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: However let it reprieve her till we see Belvile.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: That's hard, yet I will grant it.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Oh, Sir, the Colonel is just come in with his new Friend and a Spaniard of Quality, and talks of having you to Dinner with 'em.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: 'Dsheartlikins, I'm undone—I would not see 'em for the World. Harkey, Fred. lock up the Wench in your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Fear nothing, Madam, what e're he threatens, you are safe whilst in my hands.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: And, Sirrah—upon your life, say—I am not at home,—or that I am asleep—or—or any thing—away— I'l prevent their coming this way.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth ACT.

div.head: Scene I. Blunt's Chamber.
div.stage: After a great knocking as at his Chamber Door, Enter Blunt softly crossing the Stage, in his Shirt and Drawers as before.
div.l: Ned, Ned Blunt, Ned Blunt.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: The Rogues are up in Arms, 'Sheartlikins this Villainous Frederick has betray'd me, they have heard of my blessed Fortune,
Ned Blunt, Ned, Ned—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Whe he's dead Sir, without dispute dead, he has not been seen to day, let's break open the door—here—Boy—

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Ha, break open the door. d'sheartlikins that mad Fellow will be as good as his word.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Boy bring something to force the door,

div.stage: [a great noise within, at the door again.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: So, now must I speak, in my own defence, I'l try what Rhetorick will do—hold—hold what do you mean Gentlemen, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Oh Rogue art a live, prithee open the door and convince us.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Yes, I am alive Gentlemen,—but at present a little busie.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: How, Blunt grown a Man of business, come, come, open and let's see this Miracle.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: No, no, no, no, Gentlemen 'tis no great business—but —I am—at—my Devotion—d'sheartlikins will you not alow a Man time to Pray.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Turn'd Religious! a greater wonder then the first, therefore open quickly, or we shall unhinge, we shall.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: This won't do—whe hearkey Col. to tell you the plain truth, I am about a necessary affair of life—I have a wench with me—you apprehend me? the Devils in't if they be so uncivil as to disturb me now,

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: How a Wench! Nay then we must enter and partake no resistance—unless it be your Lady of Quality, and then we'l keep our distance,

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: So, the bus'ness is out.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Come, come lends more hands to the Door—now heave altogether—so well done my Boyes—

div.stage: Enter Belvile, Willmore, Fred. and Pedro. Blunt looks simply, they all laugh at him, he lays his hand on his Sword, and comes up to Wilmore.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Hearkey Sir, laugh out your laugh quickly, de ye hear, and begone. I shall spoil your sport else, 'adsheartlikins Sir, I shall the jeast has been carryed on too long—a plague upon my Tayler.—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: 'Sdeath, how the Whore has drest him, Faith Sir I'm sorry.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Are you so Sir, keep't to your self then Sir, I advise you, de'ye hear, for I can as little endure your pitty as his Mirth.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Indeed Willmore, thou wer't a little too rough with Ned Blunts Mistress, call a Person of Quality whore? and one so young, so sandsome, and so Eloquent—ha, ha, he.—

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Harkey Sir, you know me, and know I can be angry, have a care—for adsheartlikins I can fight too—I can Sir,—do you mark me—no more—

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Why so peevish good Ned, some disappointments I'le warrant—what? did the Jealous Count her Husband return just in the nick?

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Or the Devil Sir—de'ye laugh— [they laugh. Look ye settle me a good sober countenance, and that quickly too, or you shall know Ned Blunt is not—

sp.speaker: Belv,
sp.l: Not every Body, we know that.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Not an Ass to be laught at Sir,

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Unconscionable sinner, to bring a Lover so neer his happiness, a vigorous passionate Lover, and then not only cheat him of his moveables, but his very desires to.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Ah! Sir a Mistress, is a trifle with Blunt. he'l have a duzen the next time he looks abroad, his Eyes have Charms, not to be resisted, there needs no more then to expose that taking Person, to the view of the Fair, and he leads 'em all in Triumph.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Sir, tho 'I'me a stranger to you, I am asham'd at the rudeness of my Nation; and cou'd you learn who did it, wou'd assist you to make an Example of 'em.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Whe aye, there's one speaks Sense now, and han'somly; and let me tell you Gentlemen, I shou'd not have shew'd my self like a Jack Puding, thus to have made you Mirth, but that I have revenge within my power, for know, I have got into my possession a Femal, who had better have fallen under any Curse, then the ruine I design her: 'adsheartlikins she assaulted me here in my own Lodgings, and had doubtless committed a Rape upon me, had not this Sword defended me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I know not that, but O my conscience thou had Ravisht her, had shee not redeem'd her self with a Ring—let's see't Blunt.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Hah!—the Ring I gave Florinda, when we Exchange our Vows—harkey Blunt,—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: No whispering good Col. there's a Woman in the case, no whispering.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Harkey Fool, be advis'd, and conceal both the Ring and the story for your Reputations sake, do not let people know what despis'd Cullies we English are, to be cheated and abus'd by one Whore, and another rather bribe thee than be kind to thee is an Infamy to our Nation.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Come, come where's the Wench, we'l see her, let her be what she will, wee'l see her.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Ay, ay, let us see her, I can soon discover whether she be of quality, or for your diversion.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: She's in Freds Custody.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Come, come the Key,

div.stage: [To Fred. who gives him the Key, they are going.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Death, what shall I do—
Stay Gentlemen—yet if I hinder 'em I shall discover all,—hold —lets go one at once—give me the Key.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Nay hold there Col. I'le go first.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Nay no dispute, Ned and I have the gropriety of her.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Damn propriety—then we'l draw cuts, —nay no corruption good Col. come the longest Sword carries her—

div.stage: They all draw forgetting Don Pedro being as a Spaniard had the longest.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: I yield up my int'rest to you Gentlemen, and that will be; revenge sufficient.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: The Wench is yours— [to Pedro.] Pox of his Tolledo, I had forgot that.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Come Sir, I'le Conduct you to the Lady

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: To hinder him will certainly discover her—
Do'st know Dull beast what mischief thou hast done?

div.stage: Will. walking up and down out of Humour.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Aye, Aye, to trust our Fortune to Lotts, a Devil on't, 'twas madness that's the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Oh intollerable Sott—

div.stage: Enter Florinda running mask't, Pedro after her: Will. gazing round her.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Good Heaven defend me from discovery.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: 'Tis but in vain to fly me, you're fallen to my Lot.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: Sure she's undiscovered yet, but now I fear there is no way to bring her off:

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Whe what a Pox is not this my woman, the same I follow'd but now?

div.stage: [Ped. talking to Florinda, who walks up and down.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: As if I did not know yee, and your business here.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Good Heaven, I fear he does indeed—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Come, pray be kind, I know you meant to be so when you enter'd here, for these are proper Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: But Sir—perhaps the Lady will not be impos'd upon, She'l chuse her Man.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I am better bred, then not to leave her choice free.

div.stage: Enter Valeria, and is surpriz'd at sight of Don Pedro.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Don Pedro here! there's no avoiding him.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Valeria! then I'm undone,—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Oh! have I found you Sir— [To Pedro running to him. —the strangest accident—if I had breath—to tell it.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Speak—is Florinda safe? Hellena well?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ay, Ay Sir—Florinda—is safe—from any fears of you.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Why where's Florinda?—speak—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Aye, where indeed Sir, I wish I cou'd inform you, —but to hold you no longer in doubt—

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Oh what will she say—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: —She's fled away in the habit—of one of her Pages Sir— but Callis thinks you may retrieve her yet, if you make haste away, she'l tell you, Sir, the rest—if you can find her out.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l:
Dishonourable Girle, she has undone my Aime—Sir—you see my necessity of leaving you, and hope you'l Pardon it; my
Sister I know will make her flight to you; and if she do, I shall Expect she shou'd be render'd back.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: I shall consult my Love and Honour Sir.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: My dear Preserver, let me imbrace thee.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: What the Devil's all this?

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Mysterie by this light.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Come, come, make haste and get your selves married quickly, for your Brother will return again.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: I'm so surpriz'd with fears and joyes, so amaz'd to find you here in safety, I can scarce perswade my heart into a faith of what I see—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Harkey Colonel, is this that Mistress who has cost you so many sighs, and me so many quarrels with you?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: It is—pray give him the honour of your hand.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Thus it must be receiv'd then [Kneels and kisses her hand. And with it give your Pardon too.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: The Friend to Belvile may command me any thing.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Death, wou'd I might, 'tis a surprizing Beauty.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Boy, run and fetch a Father instantly.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: So, now do I stand like a Dog, and have not a syllable to plead my own Cause with: by this hand, Madam, I was never throughly confounded before, nor shall I ever more dare look up with confidence, till you are pleas'd to Pardon me.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Sir, I'le be reconcil'd to you on one condition, that you'l follow the Example of your Friend, in Marrying a Maid that does not hate you, and whose fortune (I believe) will not be unwelcome to you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Madam, had I no Inclinations that way, I shou'd obey your kind Commands.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Who Fred. marry, he has so few inclinations for Woman kind, that had he been possest of Paradice, he might have continu'd there to this day, if no Crime but Love cou'd have dis-inherited him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Oh, I do not use to boast of my intregues.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Boast, when thou dost nothing but boast; and I dare swear, wer't thou as Innocent from the sin of the Grape, as thou art from the Apple, thou might'st yet claim that right in Eden which our first Parents lost by too much Loving.

sp.speaker: Fred.
