sp.l: I wish this Lady would think me so modest a man.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l:
She wou'd be sorry then, and not like you half so well, and
I should be loath to break my word with you, which was, That if your Friend and mine agreed, it shou'd be a Match between you and I.

sp.speaker: Bred.
sp.l: Bear witness, Colonel, 'tis a Bargain.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: I have a Pardon to beg too, but adsheartlikins I am so out of Countenance, that I'm a Dog if I can say any thing to Purpose.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Sir, I heartily forgive you all.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: That's nobly said, sweet Lady,—Belvile, prithee present her her Ring again; for I find I have not Courage to approach her my self.

div.stage: [Gives him the Ring he gives to Florinda.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Sir, I have brought the Father that you sent for.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: 'Tis well, and now my dear Florinda, let's fly to compleat that mighty joy we have so long wish't and sigh'd for: —Come Fred.—you'l follow?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Your Example Sir, 'twas ever my ambition in War, and must be so in Love.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: And must not I see this juggling knot ty'd?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: No, thou shalt do us better service, and be our guard, least Don Pedro's suddain return interrupt the Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Content—I'll secure this pass.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Sir, there's a Lady without wou'd speak to you.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Conduct her in, I dare not quit my Post.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: And Sir, your Taylor waits you in your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Some comfort yet, I shall not dance naked at the Wedding.

div.stage: Enter again the Boy, conducting in Angellica in a Masquing Habit and a Vizard. Will. runs to her.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: This can be none but my pretty Gipsie—Oh, I see you can follow as well as fly—Come, confess thy self the most malicious Devil in Nature, you think you have done my bus'ness with Angellica.—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Stand off, base Villain—

div.stage: [She draws a Pistol, and holds to his Brest.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Hah, 'tis not she, who art thou? and what's thy business?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: One thou hast injur'd, and who comes to kill thee for't.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: What the Devil canst thou mean?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: By all my hopes to kill thee—

div.stage: [Holds still the Pistol to his Brest, he going back, she following still.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Prithee on, what acquaintance? for I know thee not.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Behold this face!—so lost to thy remembrance,
And then call all thy sins about thy Soul,
And let 'em dye with thee.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Angellica!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Yes, Taylor,
Does not thy guilty blood run shivering through thy Veins?
Hast thou no horrour at this sight, that tells thee,
Thou hast not long to boast thy shameful Conquest?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Faith, no Child, my blood keeps its old Ebbs and Flows still, and that usual heat too, that cou'd oblige thee with a kindness, had I but opportunity.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Devil! dost wantonDouble meaning: to play and to behave in a sexually promiscuous way with my pain—have at thy heart.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Hold, dear ViragoA wicked woman (OED)! hold thy hand a little,
I am not now at leasure to be kill'd—hold and hear me—
—Death, I think she's in earnest.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Oh if I take not heed,
My coward heart will leave me to his mercy.
—What have you, Sir, to say?—but shou'd I hear thee,
Thoud'st talk away all that is brave about me:
sp.stage: [Follows him with the Pistol to his Brest.
sp.l: And I have vow'd thy death, by all that's Sacred.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Whe then there's an end of a proper handsome Fellow,
That might a liv'd to have done good service yet;
—That's all I can say to't.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: yet—I wou'd give thee—time for—penitence.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Faith Child, I thank God, I have ever took
Care to lead a good sober, hopeful Life, and am of a Religion
That teaches me to believe, I shall depart in peace.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: So will the Devil! tell me,
How many poor believing Fools thou hast undone?
How many hearts thou hast betray'd to ruin?
—Yet these are little mischiefs to the Ills
Thoust taught mine to commit▪ thoust taught it Love?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Egad 'twas shrewdly hurt the while.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: —Love, that has rob'd it of its unconcern
Of all that Pride that taught me how to value it.
And in its room
A mean submissive Passion was convey'd,
That made me humbly bow, which I nere did
To any thing but Heaven.
—Thou, Perjur'd Man, didst this, and with thy Oaths,
Which on thy Knees, thou didst devoutly make,
Soften'd my yielding heart—And then, I was a slave—
—Yet still had been content to've worn my Chains:
Worn 'em with vanity and joy for ever,
Hadst thou not broke those Vows that put them on.
—'Twas then I was undone.

div.stage: [All this while follows him with the Pistol to his Breast.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Broke my Vows! whe where hast thou liv'd?
Amongst the Gods? for I never heard of mortal Man,
That has not broke a thousand Vows.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Oh Impudence!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Angellica! that Beauty has been too long tempting,
Not to have made a thousand Lovers languish,
Who in the Amorous Favour, no doubt have sworn
Like me: did they all dye in that Faith? still Adoring?
I do not think they did.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: No, faithless Man: had I repaid their Vows, as I did thine, I wou'd have kill'd the ingrateful that had abandon'd me.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: This Old General has quite spoil'd thee, nothing makes a Woman so vain, as being flatter'd; your old Lover ever supplies the defects of Age, with intollerable Dotage, vast Charge, and that which you call Constancy; and attributing all this to your own Merits, you domineer, and throw your Favours in's Teeth, upbraiding him still with the defects of Age, and Cuckold him as often as he deceives your Expectations. But the Gay, Young, Brisk Lover, that brings his equal Fires, and can give you dart for dart, you'l will be as nice as you sometimes.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: All this thou'st made me know, for which I hate thee.
Had I remain'd in innocent security,
I shou'd have thought all men were born my slaves,
And worn my pow'r like lightening in my Eyes,
To have destroy'd at pleasure when offended:
—But when Love held the Mirror, the undeceiving Glass
Reflected all the weakness of my Soul, and made me know
My richest treasure being lost, my Honour,
All the remaining spoil cou'd not be worth
The Conqueror's Care or Value.
—Oh how I fell like a long worship't Idol
Discovering all the Cheat.
Wou'd not the Insence and rich Sacrifice,
Which blind Devotion offer'd at my Alters,
Have fall'n to thee?
Why wou'dst thou then destroy my fancy'd pow'r.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: By Heaven thou'rt brave, and I admire thee strangely
I wish I were that dull, that constant thing
Which thou wou'dst have, and Nature never meant me:
I must, like cheerful Birds, sing in all Groves,
And perch on every Bough,
Billing the next kind she that flies to meet me;
Yet after all cou'd build my Nest with thee,
Thither repairing when I'd lov'd my round,
And still reserve a tributary Flame.
—To gain your credit, I'l pay you back your Charity,
And be oblig'd for nothing but for Love.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Oh that thou wert in earnest!
So mean a thought of me,
Wou'd turn my rage to scorn, and I shou'd pity thee,
And give thee leave to live;
Which for the publick safety of our Sex,
And my own private Injuries, I dare not do▪
Prepare
—I will no more be tempted with replies.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Sure—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Another word will damn thee! I've heard thee talk too long.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Hah! Angellica!

div.stage: [She follows him with the Pistol ready to shoot; he retires still amaz'd. Enter Don Antonio, his Arm in a Scarf, and layes hold on the Pistol.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Antonio! what Devil brought thee hither?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Love and Curiosity, seeing your Coach at door.
Let me disarm you of this unbecoming instrument of death—amongst the Number of your slaves, was there not one, worthy the Honour to have fought your quarrel?
—Who are you Sir, that are so very wretched
To merit death from her?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: One Sir, that cou'd have made a better End of an Amorous quarrel without you, than with you.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Sure 'tis some Rival,—hah—the very Man took down her Picture yesterday—the very same that set on me last night —blest opportunity—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Hold, you're mistaken Sir.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: By Heaven the very same!
—Sir, what pretensions have you to this Lady?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Sir, I do not use to be Examin'd, and am Ill at all disputes but this—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Oh hold! you see he's Arm'd with certain death;
—And you Antonio, I command you hold,
By all the Passion you've so lately vow'd me.

div.stage: Enter Don Pedro, sees Antonio, and stays.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Hah, Antonio! and Angellica!

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: When I refuse obedience to your Will,
May you destroy me with your Mortal hate.
By all that's Holy I Adore you so,
That even my Rival, who has Charms enough
To make him fall a Victim to my jealousie
Shall live, nay and have leave to love on still.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: What's this I hear?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Ah thus! twas thus! he talkt, and I believ'd.
—(Antonio,) yesterday,
I'd not have sold my Intrest in his heart,
For all the Sword has won and lost in Battail.
—But now to show my utmost of contempt,
I give thee Life—which if thou wou'dst preserve,
Live where my Eyes may never see thee more,
Live to undo some one, whose Soul may prove,
So bravely constant to revenge my Love.

div.stage: [Goes out, Ant. follows, but Ped. pulls him back.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Antonio—stay.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Don Pedro—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: What Coward fear was that prevented thee
From meeting me this morning on the Molo?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Meet thee?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Yes me; I was the Man that dar'd thee to't.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Hast thou so often seen me fight in War,
To find no better Cause to excuse my absence?
—I sent my Sword and one to do thee right,
Finding my self uncapable to use a Sword.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: But 'twas Florinda's Quarrel that we fought,
And you to shew how little you esteem'd her,
Sent me your Rival, giving him your Intrest.
—But I have found the cause of this affront,
And when I meet you fit for the dispute,
—I'l tell you my resentment.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I shall be ready, Sir, e're long to do you reason.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: If I cou'd find Florinda, now whilst my angers high,
I think I shou'd be kind, and give her to Belvile in revenge.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Faith, Sir, I know not what you wou'd do, but I believe the Priest within has been so kind.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: How! my Sister Married?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I hope by this time he is, and bedded too, or he has not
My longings about him.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Dares he do this! does he not fear my Pow'r?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Faith not at all, if you will 'go in, and thank him for the favour he has done your Sister, so, if not, Sir, my Pow'rs greater in this house than yours, I have a damn'd surly Crew here, that will keep you till the next Tide, and then clap you on bord for Prise; my Ship lies but a League off the Molo, and we shall show your Donship a damn'd Tramontana"Dwelling or situated beyond, or pertaining to the far side of, the mountains (orig. and in reference to Italy, the Alps...hence, foreign...occupied by a non-Italian." This word could also have, "the connotation [of] 'uncouth, unpolished, barbarous'." ("tramontane, adj. and n." OED Online. Oxford University Press, September 2016. Web. 5 December 2016. Rovers Trick.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.l: This Rogue's in some new Mischief—hah Pedro return'd!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Colonel Belvile, I hear you have Married my Sister?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: You have heard truth then, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Have I so; then, Sir, I wish you Joy.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: By this imbrace I do, and I am glad on't.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Are you in earnest?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: By our long Friendship and my obligations to thee, I am,
The sudain change, I'le give you reasons for anon,
Come lead me to my Sister,
That she may know, I now approve her choice.

div.stage: Will. goes to follow them. Enter Hellena as before in Boys Clothes, and pulls him back.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Ha! my Gipsie:—now a thousand blessings on thee for this kindness, Egad Child I was e'en in dispair of ever seeing thee again; my Friends are all provided for within, each Man his kind Woman.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Hah! I thought they had serv'd me some such trick!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: And I was e'en resolv'd to go aboard, and condemn my self to my lone Cabin, and the thoughts of thee.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: And cou'd you have left me behind, wou'd you have been so ill natur'd?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Whe twou'd have broke my Heart Child:—but since we are met again, I defie foul weather to part us.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: And wou'd you be a Faithful Friend, now if a Maid shou'd trust you?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: For a Friend I cannot promise, thou art of a form so Excellent a Face and Humour, too good for cold dull Friendship; I am parlously"In a parlous manner; esp. perilously, dangerously; precariously; desperately," ("parlously, adv." OED Online. Oxford University Press, September 2016. Web. 5 December 2016.) afraid of being in Love Child, and you have not forgot how severely you have us'd me?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: That's all one, such usage you must still look for, to find out all your Haunts, to raile at you to all that Love you, till I have made you love only me in your own defence, because no body else will love.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: But hast thou no better quality, to recommend thy self by.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Faith none Captain:—whe 'twill be the greater Charity to take me for thy Mistress. I am alone Child, a kind of Orphan Lover, and why I shou'd dye a Maid, and in a Captains hands too, I do not understand,

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l:
Egad, I was never claw'd away with Broad-sides from any Female before, thou hast one Vertue I Adore, good Nature; I hate a Coy demure Mistress, she's as troublesome as a Colt, I'l break none; no give me a mad Mistress when Mew'd, and in
flying on I dare trust upon the wing, that whil'st she's kind will come to the Lure.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Nay as kind as you will good Capt. whil'st it lasts, but let's lose no time,

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: My time's as precious to me, as thine can be, therefore dear creature, since we are so well agreed, let's retire to my Chamber, and if ever thou wert treated with such Savory Love!— come—my beds prepar'd for such a guest all clean and Sweet as thy fair self, I love to steal a Dish and a Bottle with a Friend, and hate long Graces—come let's retire and fall too.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: 'Tis but getting my consent, and the bus'ness is soon done, let but old Gaffer"A term applied originally by country people to an elderly man or one whose position entitled him to respect." Or, "Used simply as a title of address, often with not intimation of respect," ("gaffer, n." OED Online. Oxford University Press, September 2016. Web. 5 December 2016.) Himen and his Priest, say amen to't, and I dare lay my Mothers daughter by as proper a Fellow as your Father's Son, without fear or blushing,

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Hold, hold, no Bugg"A word meant to frighten or terrify; a word that causes dread," († bug-word | bug's-word, n. OED Online. Oxford University Press, September 2016. Web. 5 December 2016.) words Child, Priest and Hymen, prithee add a Hang-man to 'em to make up the consort,—no, no, we'l have no Vows but Love, Child, nor witness but the Lover, the kind Deity injoyn naught but Love! and injoy! Himen and Priest wait still upon Portion, and Joynture; Love and Beauty have their own Ceremonies; Marriage is as certain a bane to Love, as lending Money is to Friendship: I'l neither ask nor give a Vow,—tho' I cou'd be content to turn Gipsie, and become a left-handed bride-groom, to have the pleasure of working that great Miracle of making a Maid a Mother, if you durst venture; 'tis upse Gipsie that, and if I miss, I'l lose my Labour.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: And if you do not lose, what shall I get? a cradle full of noise and mischief, with a pack of repentance at my back? can you teach me to weave Incle"A kind of linen tape, formerly much used for various purposes," ("inkle, n." OED Online. Oxford University Press, September 2016. Web. 5 December 2016.) to pass my time with? 'tis upse Gipsie that too.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I can teach thee to Weave a true loves knot better.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: So can my dog.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Well, I see we are both upon our Guards, and I see there's no way to conquer good Nature, but by yielding,—here— give me thy hand—one kiss and I am thine—

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: One kiss! how like my Page he speaks; I am resolv'd you shall have none, for asking such a sneaking sum,—he that will be satisfied with one kiss, will never dye of that longing; good Friend, single kiss, is all your talking come to this?—a kiss, a caudle! farewel Captain, single kiss.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l:
Nay if we part so, let me dye like a bird upon a bough,
at the Sheriffs charge, by Heaven both the Indies, shall not buy thee from me. I adore thy Humour and will marry thee, and we are so of one Humour, it must be a bargain—give me thy hand.— [Kisses her Hand. And now let the blind ones (Love and Fortune) do their worst.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Whe God-a-mercy Captain!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: But harkey—the bargain is now made; but is it not fit we shou'd know each others Names? that when we have reason to curse one another hereafter (and People ask me who 'tis I give to the Devil) I may at least be able to tell, what Family you came of.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Good reason, Captain; and where I have cause, (as I doubt not but I shall have plentiful) that I may know at whom to throw my—blessings—I beseech ye your Name.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I am call'd Robert the Constant.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: A very fine name; pray was it your Faulkner or Butler that Chisten'd you? do they not use to Whistle when they call you?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I hope you have a better, that a man may name without crossing himself, you are so merry with mine.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: I am call'd Hellena the Inconstant.

div.stage: Enter Pedro, Belvile, Florinda, Fred. Valleria.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Hah! Hellena!

sp.speaker: Florin.
sp.l: Hellenah!

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: The very same—hah my Brother! now Captain shew your Love and Courage; stand to your Arms, and defend me bravely, or I am lost for Ever.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: What's this I hear! false Girle, how came you hither, and what's your bus'ness? Speak.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Hold off Sir, you have leave to parly only.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: I had e'en as good tell it, as you guess it; Faith Brother my bus'ness, is the same with all living Creatures of my Age, to love, and be beloved, and here's the Man.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Perfidious Maid, hast thou deceiv'd me too, deceiv'd thy self and Heaven;

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: 'Tis time enough to make my peace with that,
Be you but kind let me alone with Heaven,

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l:
Belvile, I did not expect this false play from you; was't
not enough you'd gain Florinda (which I pardon'd) but your lewd Friends too must be inricht with the spoyls of a Noble Family?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Faith Sir, I am as much surpriz'd at this as you can be: Yet Sir, my Friends are Gentlemen, and ought to be Esteem'd for their Misfortunes, since they have the Glory to suffer with the best of Men and Kings; 'tis true, he's a Rover of Fortune, Yet a Prince, aboard his little wooden World.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: What's this to the maintenance of a Woman of her Birth and Quality.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Faith Sir, I can boast of nothing but a Sword which does me right where e're I come, and has defended a worse Cause then a Womans; and since I lov'd her before I either knew her Birth or Name, I must pursue my resolution, and marry her.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: And is all your holy intent of becoming a Nun, debauch't into a desire of Man?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Whe—I have consider'd the matter Brother, and find, the Three hundred thousand Crowns my Uncle left me (and you cannot keep from me) will be better laid out in Love than in Religion, and turn to as good an account,—let most voyces carry it, for Heaven or the Captain?
All cry, a Captain? a Captain?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Look yee Sir, 'tis a clear case.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Oh I am mad—if I refuse, my lifes in danger— [aside. —Come—there's one motive induces me—take her— I shall now be free from fears of her Honour, guard it you now, if you can, I have been a slave to't long enough,

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Faith Sir, I am of a Nation, that are of opinion a womans Honour is not worth guarding when she has a mind to part with it.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Well said Captain.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: This was your Plot Mistress, but I hope you have married one that will revenge my quarrel to you—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: There's no altering Destinie, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Sooner than a Womans Will, therefore I forgive you all—and wish you may get my Father's Pardon as Easily; which I fear.

div.stage: Enter Blunt drest in a Spanish Habit, looking very ridiculously; his Man a justing his Band.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'Tis very well Sir—

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l:
Well Sir, 'dshearlikins I tell you 'tis damnable Ill Sir, —a Spanish habit good Lord! Cou'd the Devil and my Taylor
devise no other punishment for me, but the Mode of a Nation I abominate?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: What's the matter Ned?

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Pray view me round, and judge,—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I must confess thou art a kind of an odd Figure.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: In a Spanish habit with a Vengeance! I had rather be in the Inquisition for Judaisme, than in this Doublet and Breeches, a Pillory were an easie Coller, to this three handfuls high; and these Shoes too, are worse, then the stocks with the sole an Inch shorter than my Foot: In fine, Gentlemen, methinks I look altogether like a Bag of Bayes"A bag of bay leaves used in cooking." (Canfield, J. D., and Sneidern M.-L. Von. The Broadview Anthology of Restoration and Early Eighteenth-Century Drama. Peterborough, Ont: Broadview Press, 2004. Print) stufft full of Fooles flesh.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Methinks 'tis well, and makes thee look e'n Cavalier: Come Sir, settle your face, and salute our Friends, Lady—

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Hah!—say'st thou so my Little Rover— [To Hell. Lady—(if you be one) give me leave to kiss your hand, and tell you adshearlikins for all I look so, I am your humble Servant,— a Pox of my Spanish habit.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Hark—what's this?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Sir, as the Custome is, the gay people in Masquerade who make every mans House their own, are coming up:

div.stage: Enter several Men and Women in Masquing Habits with Musick, they put themselves in order and Dance.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Adsheartlikins, wou'd twere lawful to pull off their false faces, That I might see if my Doxie were not amongst e'm.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Ladies and Gentlemen, since you are come so apropo, you must take a small Collation with us.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Whilst we'le to the Good Man within, who stayes to give us a CastA look or view ("cast, n." OED Online. Oxford University Press, September 2016. Web. 5 December 2016.). of his Office. [To Hell. —Have you no trembling at the near approach?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: No more than you have in an Engagement or a Tempest.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Egad thou'rt a brave Girle, and I admire thy Love and Courage.
Lead on, no other Dangers they can dread,
Who Venture in the Storms o'th' Marriage Bed.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: THe Banisht Cavaliers! a Roving Blade!
A Popish Carnival! a Masquerade!
The Devel's in't if this will please the Nation,
In these our blessed times of Reformation,
When ConventicklingA religious meeting of an unsanctioned or clandestine nature ("conventicle, n." OED Online. Oxford University Press, September 2016. Web. 5 December 2016.). is so much in fashon.
And yet—
That Mutinous Tribe less Factions do beget,
Than your continual differing in Wit;
Your Judgment's (as your Passion's) a disease:
Nor Muse nor Miss your Appetite can please;
Your grown as Nice as queasie Consciences,
Who's each Convulsion, when the Spirit moves,
Damns every thing, that Maggot disapproves.
With CantingHypocritical ("ˈcanting, adj.2." OED Online. Oxford University Press, September 2016. Web. 5 December 2016.). Rule you wou'd the Stage refine,
And to Dull Method all our Sense confine.
With th' Insolence of Common Wealths you rule,
Where each gay Fop, and Politick grave Fool
On Monarch Wit impose, without controul.
As for the last, who seldom sees a Play,

Unless it be the old Black FryersA major London theater in which the Shakespeare company performed during the winter until 1642, when all the playhouses were closed (Gurr, Andrew. "London’s Blackfriars Playhouse and the Chamberlains Men’." Inside Shakespeare: Essays on the Blackfriars Stage (2006): 17-33.). way,
Shaking his empty NoddleHead ("noddle, n.1." OED Online. Oxford University Press, September 2016. Web. 5 December 2016.). o're Bamboo,
He Crys,—Good Faith, these Playes will never do.
—Ah, Sir, in my young days, what lofty Wit,
What high strain'd Scenes of Fighting there were Writ:
These are slight airy Toys. But tell me, pray,
What has the House of Commons done to day?
Then shews his Politicks, to let you see,
Of State Affairs he'l judge as notably,
As he can do of Wit and Poetry.
The younger Sparks,A foppish, affected type of man ("spark, n.2." OED Online. Oxford University Press, September 2016. Web. 5 December 2016.). who hither do resort,
Cry,—
Pox o' your gentile things, give us more Sport;
—Damn me, I'm sure 'twill never please the Court.
Such Fops are never pleas'd unless the Play
Be stufft with Fools, as brisk and dull as they:
Such might the Half-Crown spare, and in a Glass
At home, behold a more Accomplisht Ass,
Where they may set their Cravats, Wigs and Faces,
And Practice all their Buffonry Grimasses:
See how this—Huff becomes,—this Damny,—stare,—
Which they at home may act, because they dare,
But—must with prudent caution do elsewhere.

Oh that our Nokes, or Tony LeeJames Stokes and Anthony Leigh were celebrated comic actors of the period, often appearing alongside one another (Chernaik, Warren. “Nokes , James (c.1642–1696).” Warren Chernaik Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Ed. H. C. G. Matthew and Brian Harrison. Oxford: OUP, 2004. Online ed. Ed. David Cannadine. Jan. 2008. 5 Dec. 2016). cou'd show
A Fop but half so much to th' life as you.

div.head: Post-script.
div.l: This Play had been sooner in Print, but for a Report about the Town (made by some either very Malitious or very Ignorant) that 'twas ThomasoThe Rover borrows heavily from Thomas Killigrew's Thomaso, or, The Wanderer, though Behn seems to minimize the extent to which she borrowed from it here (DeRitter, Jones. "The Gypsy," The Rover", and the Wanderer: Aphra Behn's Revision of Thomas Killigrew." Restoration: Studies in English Literary Culture, 1660-1700 10.2 (1986): 82-92.). alter'd; which made the Book-sellers fear some trouble from the Proprietor of that Admirable Play, which indeed has Wit enough to stock a Poet, and is not to be peec't or mended by any but the Excellent Author himself; That I have stoln some hints from it, may be a proof, that I valu'd it more than to pretend to alter it; had I had the Dexterity of some Poets, who are not more Expert in stealing than in the Art of Concealing, and who even that way out-do the Spartan-Boyes. I might have appropriated all to my self, but I, vainly proud of my Iudgment, hang out the Sign of Angellica, (the only stoln Object) to give Notice where a great part of the Wit dwelt; tho if the Play of the Novella were as well worth remembring as Thomaso, they might (bating the Name) have as well said, I took it from thence: I will only say the Plot and Bus'ness (not to boast on't) is my own: as for the Words and Characters, I leave the Reader to judge and compare 'em with Thomaso, to whom I recommend the great Entertainment of reading it, tho had this succeeded ill, I shou'd have had no need of imploring that Justice from the Criticks, who are naturally so kind to any that pretend to usurp their Dominion, they wou'd doubtless have given me the whole Honour on't. Therefore I will only say in English what the famous Virgil does in Latin; I make Verses, and others have the Fame.
